"The first cases of contagion by the new coronavirus in Portugal are confirmed. One patient tested positive, while another awaits a counter-analysis that will allow definitive confirmation by the National Institute Dr. Ricardo Jorge (INSA).    The Portuguese authorities will now track the steps of these patients from the day they showed the first symptoms in an attempt to identify the people with whom they were in contact. The people closest to them are already "under surveillance".    Source: https://archive.vn/QSKEe

In Portugal, there are currently 21 confirmed cases and 47 people are still awaiting laboratory results , which led the Government to take containment measures - such as the closure of schools and the suspension of visits to homes, hospitals and prisons in the North.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201214181839/https://www.publico.pt/2020/03/07/sociedade/noticia/faculdades-fechadas-visitas-proibidas-norte-numero-infectados-crescer-60-1906845

"Two public schools in the Algarve are now closed (...) the General Directorate of Health (DGS) announced closure of all schools in the Felgueiras and Lousada areas, due to a second child testing positive for Covid-19".    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200507074022/https://www.portugalresident.com/covid-19-portugal-round-up/

March 9 - "The meeting also provided guidance on the suspension of any events, such as weddings and the celebration of masses, with more than 150 people in the municipalities of Felgueiras and Lousada, in the district of Porto - the two areas most affected by the outbreak of the new coronavirus in Portugal. The Minister of Internal Affairs, stressed that events of "any type" in these areas are prohibited, from a wedding, funeral, mass or sports event. At a national level, the executive recommended the suspension of events in open spaces with more than 5000 people, and closed-door events with more than 1000 participants, "in line with guidelines that have been taken in the generality of European Union countries" , said the minister of Internal Administration, Eduardo Cabrita."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210621235949/https://www.dn.pt/pais/governo-suspende-voos-entre-portugal-e-zonas-mais-afetadas-de-italia-11906555.html    Note: Code subject to interpretation - guidelines are not very clear and could be interpreted as a strong recommendation to suspend or an actual suspension.

Nightclubs and similar establishments are required to close, bars and restaurants have to limit the number of customers  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200509095926/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/download-ficheiros/ficheiro.aspx?v=10317e83-589c-49b6-91ab-26341e747058

Government implements an extraordinary income support scheme to workers who need to stay home to take care of dependants and to those who had lost their income due to reduction in economic activity. This is caped at 50% of the income or the minimum wage for informal workers (700 euros per month).    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200509072543/http://www.seg-social.pt/apoio-extraordinario-a-reducao-da-atividade-economica-de-trabalhador-independente  "É criado um apoio financeiro excepcional aos trabalhadores por conta de outrem que tenham de ficar em casa a acompanhar os filhos até 12 anos, no valor de 66% da remuneração base (33% a cargo do empregador, 33% a cargo da Segurança Social). Para os trabalhadores independentes, é criado um apoio financeiro excepcional aos que tenham de ficar em casa a acompanhar os filhos até 12 anos, no valor de 1/3 da remuneração média, bem como um apoio extraordinário à redução da atividade económica de trabalhador independente e diferimento do pagamento de contribuições"

Visits to homes across the country suspended. PM announced that the limitation that exists in the North is extended to the entire country, which implies a suspension of visits to the elderly. March 12 -"Portugal’s government ordered on Thursday to shut down all schools nationwide from next week (i.e. Monday, March 16) to contain the coronavirus epidemic, which Prime Minister Antonio Costa labelled a threat to survival in a televised address to the nation.  The suspension of classes encompasses all the education system from kindergartens to universities, both public and private, and will be in force until further evaluation on April 9. There are about 2 million school children in Portugal, a nation of just over 10 million people."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201509/https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-health-coronavirus-portugal/portugal-orders-schools-night-clubs-shut-due-to-coronavirus-idUKKBN20Z3OD?edition-redirect=uk

President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa declared a 15-day nationwide state of emergency on March 18, which restricted non-essential travel and led thousands of businesses to close their doors. Parliament approved exceptional measures suspending evictions and cuts in the provision of water, gas, and electricity due to income loss caused by the coronavirus.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200509085737/https://www.publico.pt/2020/03/18/politica/noticia/medidas-excepcionais-aprovadas-nao-ha-despejos-corte-agua-luz-1908429    "sejam suspensas as acções de despejo durante o período em que vigorar a pandemia e que não possam ser cortados os abastecimentos de água, luz ou gás por falta de pagamento devido a desemprego, quebra dos rendimentos ou por o cliente sofrer de covid-19"

"Starting on Thursday (March 26), the number of tests for the new coronavirus will be greatly expanded, with doctors at the local level, in each region, being able to decide who will be tested. Just have a fever, just have a cough" (...)"  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210622002443/https://www.dn.pt/pais/testes-vao-ser-muito-alargados-basta-ter-tosse-garante-a-dgs-11977495.html

"The Council of Ministers today approved a new set of extraordinary measures to respond to the epidemiological situation of the new Coronavirus-COVID-19:  (...) the third term will begin on April 14th, with in-person teaching and training activities in schools being suspended; - Primary education classes will continue until the end of the school year will continue remotely (...) - Once the COVID-19 epidemiological situation has been evaluated, the Government may decide to resume classroom classes for students in the 11th and 12th grades, ensuring social distancing (classes, classrooms, classes) and justifying the absences of students whose guardians choose not to attend; - classes for the 10th grade will continue taking place remotely until the end of the academic year. (...) the 3rd term will end on June 26, 2020."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210617203434/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/governo/comunicado-de-conselho-de-ministros?i=340

Governments prohibits internal travel during Easter holiday    Link: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/noticia?i=governo-limita-circulacao-intermunicipal-no-periodo-da-pascoa

Between midnight on Thursday, April 9th, until midnight on Monday, April 13th, any travel outside the municipality of habitual residence will be prohibited . Exception for those who have to travel to the workplace, which must be accompanied by a statement that proves it .  In the same period, all national airports will be closed for passenger traffic . Cargo flights, humanitarian nature, Portuguese repatriation flights or State flights and military nature are maintained.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425182614/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2020-04-02-As-novas-medidas-do-estado-de-emergencia

"Electricity (...) and natural gas (...) have already been the target of several exceptional measures (...)  In addition to a 3% cut for those provided in the regulated market and a longer period for payment of invoices, customers also have the guarantee of no cuts due to non-payment until the end of June (...) but this does not exempt customers from the obligation to pay. Providers can still send cut-off notices for non-payment, but that notice is now 50 days instead of the previous 20-day deadline (... This Wednesday, the Parliament also approved the suspension of supply cuts in several essential services, including electricity and natural gas, during the state of emergency and in the following month.  (...) This Wednesday, in Parliament, a bill (...) was approved which provides, during a state of emergency, unemployed consumers or whose household shows a decrease in income of more than 20% compared to the previous month may apply for termination unilateral telecommunications contracts without compensation to the supplier. Like energy and water, communications have been included in the range of essential services that cannot be cut off during the emergency period and the following month (...)".  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210620153138/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2020-04-09-Covid-19.-Eletricidade-gas-agua-e-comunicacoes-que-alivios-existem-durante-o-estado-de-emergencia-

"According to the Regional Health Authority (ARS) of Lisbon and Vale do Tejo, only users who have a prescription from a family doctor or who have an indication for the line SNS24 - 808 24 24 24 should go to the test centers.    Anyone who does not have a family doctor assigned, is, even so, registered in a health unit or a health center and must also contact by telephone, despite not having a fixed health team assigned.    The SNS24 line can even refer a potential patient to an ADC (Dedicated Area to Covid-19).    For the rest, only suspected cases of Covid-19 should be resorted to these services, which the Directorate-General of Health currently determines as people suffering from symptoms such as persistent cough, fever with a temperature of 38.0ºC or more and respiratory distress."    Source: https://archive.vn/oguNR

During the long weekend (due the the Labour Day bank holiday) the government has restricted travel between provinces.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200509091052/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/noticia?i=proibido-circular-entre-concelhos-no-fim-de-semana-do-1-de-maio    "O Governo vai decretar, para o fim-de-semana prolongado do 1.º de Maio, a mesma norma que adotou para a Páscoa, com proibição de deslocações para fora do concelho de residência"

Decree-Law (DL) 20/2020 says that “the use of masks or visors is mandatory when using public passenger transport”, stressing that non-compliance “constitutes an offense, punishable by a minimum fine” of 120 euros and a maximum of 350 euros.    The diploma, which comes into force on Sunday, May 3, also states that “the use of masks or visors is mandatory for access or permanence in spaces and commercial establishments and the provision of services, services and buildings serving the public and in educational establishments and daycare centers by teaching and non-teaching staff and students over the age of six ”.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201015094042/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/minimum-fines-of-120-euros-for-no-mask/53982

"On 30 April 2020, the Government adopted a strategy for the de-escalation of containment measures, setting 18 May as the possible date to restart schooling. Only learners in the 11th and 12th year of education (second and third year of VET programmes) were expected to get back to schools, the aim being to enable them to complete their studies to access higher education. On 14 May the Government restructured the exceptional measures for the organisation and functioning of education and training activities in the context of the pandemic. The new measures specified that:  learners in the last two grades of compulsory education (11th and 12th year of education) should return to schools on 18 May"  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425114710/https://www.cedefop.europa.eu/en/news-and-press/news/portugal-responses-covid-19-outbreak

On 4th of May Portugal started the first phase in easing the restrictions:  Barbers and hair salons are allowed open for clients who make an appointment and must follow guidelines of the health authorities; Small shops with less than 200m2 can open but cannot have more than 5 clients per 100m2 and masks are mandatory; Public services are open to everyone with an appointment and it is mandatory to wear masks; Libraries and Archives are also allowed to reopen.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200506233239/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2020-05-03-Isto-e-tudo-o-que-pode-voltar-a-fazer-a-partir-desta-segunda-feira--mas-lembre-se-mantem-se-o-dever-civico-de-recolhimento--1

On 4th of May Portugal started the first phase in easing the restrictions[14]:    Barbers and hair salons are open but with health restrictions and appointments;  Small shops with less than 200m2 can open but cannot have more than 5 clients/100m2 and all should use masks;  People can use the public transportation if remote work cannot be achieved. Can only be filled until 2/3 and all passengers must use a mask;  All public services are open to everyone with an appointment and is an obligation the use of a mask;  Physical exercise only in the outdoor;  Libraries and Archives are open;  Cannot have more than 10 people together.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200506233239/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2020-05-03-Isto-e-tudo-o-que-pode-voltar-a-fazer-a-partir-desta-segunda-feira--mas-lembre-se-mantem-se-o-dever-civico-de-recolhimento--1

Can only be filled until 2/3 and all passengers must use a mask;  All public services are open to everyone with an appointment and is an obligation the use of a mask;  Physical exercise only in the outdoor;  Libraries and Archives are open;  Cannot have more than 10 people together. On 4th of May Portugal started the first phase in easing the restrictions. People can use the public transportation if remote work is not possible, however, masks are mandatory and capacity is limited to 2/3.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200506233239/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2020-05-03-Isto-e-tudo-o-que-pode-voltar-a-fazer-a-partir-desta-segunda-feira--mas-lembre-se-mantem-se-o-dever-civico-de-recolhimento--1

On 4th of May Portugal started the first phase in easing the restrictions. The civic duty to stay at home is now in place - i.e. individuals should prioritize activities that do not imply social contact and avoid circulate in public places, except for authorized reasons (the list includes 25+ exceptions to this rule http://web.archive.org/web/20210620185609/https://www.tsf.pt/portugal/sociedade/as-25-excecoes-ao-dever-civico-de-recolhimento-em-casa-12142163.html)  Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20200506233239/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2020-05-03-Isto-e-tudo-o-que-pode-voltar-a-fazer-a-partir-desta-segunda-feira--mas-lembre-se-mantem-se-o-dever-civico-de-recolhimento--1  Note: Downgraded to 1 since it seems more appropriate: 1) given the current situation of the country and easing in the restrictiona; 2) for the fact that staying at home is more of an individual decision and 3) the list of exceptions is quite extensive.

The 1st phase of the deconfinement plan started on May 4th. No specific intercity or interstate travel restrictions were announced.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210303114155/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/download-ficheiros/ficheiro.aspx?v=%3d%3dBAAAAB%2bLCAAAAAAABACztDA0BQCOH%2fEWBAAAAA%3d%3d

Portugal is now under a state of calamity. However, measures implemented during the state of emergency namely those linked to electricity, gas and telecommunications will only end one month after the state of emergency (see below):    "Electricity (...) and natural gas (...) have already been the target of several exceptional measures (...) In addition to a 3% cut for those provided in the regulated market and a longer period for payment of invoices, customers also have the guarantee of no cuts due to non-payment until the end of June (...) but this does not exempt customers from the obligation to pay. Providers can still send cut-off notices for non-payment, but that notice is now 50 days instead of the previous 20-day deadline (... This Wednesday, the Parliament also approved the suspension of supply cuts in several essential services, including electricity and natural gas, during the state of emergency and in the following month. (...) This Wednesday, in Parliament, a bill (...) was approved which provides, during a state of emergency, unemployed consumers or whose household shows a decrease in income of more than 20% compared to the previous month may apply for termination unilateral telecommunications contracts without compensation to the supplier. Like energy and water, communications have been included in the range of essential services that cannot be cut off during the emergency period and the following month (...)". Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210620153138/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2020-04-09-Covid-19.-Eletricidade-gas-agua-e-comunicacoes-que-alivios-existem-durante-o-estado-de-emergencia-    Sources:   https://web.archive.org/web/20200506233239/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2020-05-03-Isto-e-tudo-o-que-pode-voltar-a-fazer-a-partir-desta-segunda-feira--mas-lembre-se-mantem-se-o-dever-civico-de-recolhimento--1  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620153138/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2020-04-09-Covid-19.-Eletricidade-gas-agua-e-comunicacoes-que-alivios-existem-durante-o-estado-de-emergencia-

"The prime minister, António Costa, announced that the Portuguese contribution, from public and private entities, will be equal to 10 million euros in the scope of the “Coronavirus Global Response international pledging conference", an initiative promoted by the European Commission.    António Costa made this announcement of 10 million euros for the conference of donors — 1.55 million from the Government and 8.45 million euros from private companies and institutions — an amount intended to accelerate the development of vaccine and treatments for the disease (...) With this initiative, the European Commission “aims to join the efforts of governments, entrepreneurs, foundations and citizens of the European Union to collect 7.5 billion euros”. These 7.5 billion euros, according to the European Commission, are intended “to accelerate the development, production and equitable access to vaccines, diagnoses and treatments” of Covid-19."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200520234824/https://eco.sapo.pt/2020/05/04/portugal-da-10-milhoes-para-investigacao-global-contra-o-virus/    Note: Did not code the actual amount since there are no details of the percentage of the money donated that will specifically be used to support vaccine development.
May 7 - Summer festivals were cancelled until September 30, 2020.  Source: https://archive.vn/hQFLC

May 8 - "The suspension of the termination of the lease agreements and the execution of permanent private housing and mortgage will remain, after all, until September 30, 2020 (...) The Government decided to create an exceptional regime to suspend the counting of the terms of lease contracts or their renewals, in response to the crisis caused by the Covid-19 pandemic , in what was and continues to be an exceptional period of restrictions on the movement of people, given the epidemiological situation in the country. In practice, contracts for houses about to expire in the coming months will continue to be extended.    The draft law that the Executive led by António Costa delivered to the Parliament provided that "the effects of denunciations of housing and non-housing lease contracts will be suspended until June 30, 2020". And the same with regard to  "foreclosure on property that constitutes the debtor's own and permanent dwelling and also the expiry of housing and non-housing lease contracts, except in cases where the tenant does not object to the end of the contract ”.    But in the end, the  measure will last until September 30, following  an amendment proposal made by the Socialist Party."      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210620152522/https://www.idealista.pt/news/especiais/covid-19/2020/05/08/43289-arrendamento-aprovada-suspensao-de-denuncia-de-contratos-ate-30-de-setembro

Pre schoolsl and high schools reopen as 11 and 12 graders (who will have to sit national examinations) return to school. Recess must not take place outside of the classrooms and classes have to be distributed in different shifts to avoid large gatherings. Classes for other students continue to take place remotely.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200520231404/https://www.idealista.pt/news/especiais/covid-19/2020/05/18/43376-segunda-fase-de-desconfinamento-em-portugal-o-que-muda-a-partir-de-hoje

"Portugal enters this Monday, May 18, 2020, in the second phase of the deconfinement plan defined by the Government (...) As of today, schools, day care centers, restaurants, cafes and some stores will open their doors again, but with several rules.  In general, the range of commercial establishments that may be in operation is extended , namely local stores with direct access from the street and limited in size to 400 square meters (m2) – or larger, by decision of the local authorities. They also have the green light to open cafes, patisseries, restaurants and similar establishments, as long as their occupancy does not exceed 50% of their capacity and all hygiene and sanitary guidelines of the Directorate-General for Health defined for the sector are met. Rules are also established for access to museums, monuments, palaces, archaeological sites and other similar places (...)"  Note: Code remains unchanged since for e.g. bars, clubs, large store remain closed.

"Celebrations and other type of events, that imply gatherings with more than 10 people, are not allowed."  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200520231404/https://www.idealista.pt/news/especiais/covid-19/2020/05/18/43376-segunda-fase-de-desconfinamento-em-portugal-o-que-muda-a-partir-de-hoje

May 18 - The Directorate-General for Health (DGS) has published information defining the requirements for resuming visits to Residential Structures for the Elderly and Integrated Continuing Care Units.  - The institution must create a plan for operationalizing the visits and identify a professional responsible for the process, informing family members and visitors about the conditions of the visits.  - Visits must be previously scheduled and there must be a register of visitors that includes data such as date, time, name, contact and resident visited.   - All visits must comply with rules of physical distance, respiratory etiquette and hand hygiene.  - People with signs or symptoms of COVID-19 or who have contacted a suspected or confirmed case in the past 14 days should not visit or receive visits.  - Visits must have a limited time, and must not exceed 90 minutes. According to the information, visitors should wear a mask, preferably a surgical one, during the entire period of stay in the institution and should not take personal objects, foodstuffs or other products.  - In a first phase, it is recommended that each user has one visit per week, but this limit "can be adjusted according to the conditions of the institution and the local epidemiological situation, in conjunction with the local Health authority and according to the risk assessment".  - Visitors must not circulate through the institution or use the users' sanitary facilities, and a sanitary facility for their exclusive use may be defined.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201214180619/https://covid19.min-saude.pt/dgs-publica-requisitos-para-visitas-a-lares-de-idosos/

António Costa affirmed that the lifting of a set of restrictions that involve agglomerations of people is postponed, maintaining “the rule of banning gatherings of more than 10 people in Lisbon, while the rest of the country will evolve to 20 people”.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210425153441/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/noticia?i=conselho-de-ministros-aprova-nova-fase-de-desconfinamento-com-excecao-para-lisboa

The Portuguese Government extended, from May 18th until June 15th, the ban on flights to and from Portugal to and from countries outside the European Union. Countries associated with the Schengen area and Portuguese-speaking countries are exempt from the ban. Other exceptions are the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Venezuela, Canada and South Africa, “given the presence of important Portuguese communities".    https://web.archive.org/web/20200524163643/https://www.publico.pt/2020/05/14/economia/noticia/covid19-governo-prolonga-ate-15-junho-interdicao-voos-ue-1916569

In Portugal, day care centers and nurseries reopened on June 1st. Secondary school students started to take face-to-face classes in subjects with national exams. "Resolution of the Council of Ministers 43-A/2020 of 12 June extended, until 30 June, on an exceptional and temporary basis, the control of persons at borders between Portugal and Spain (...) all flights from and to Spain are suspended, with some exceptions (for e.g. state aircraft, armed forces, flights for the transportation of goods and mail, humanitarian flights or for medical emergency). Passengers from European countries outside the Schengen Area are allowed to enter the flights from those countrie(...) Road traffic is prohibited, with some exceptions (e.g. international transport of goods and passengers, cross-border workers).  Order 6251-A/2020 of 12 June extends the ban on air traffic to and from Portugal for all flights to and from countries outside the European Union. The Government decided today, June 22, to extend the state of calamity in 15 parishes in five municipalities of the Lisbon Metropolitan Area (AML) where the newest Covid-19 contagions are located, as well as to reset the maximum limit of 10 people per gathering.  At the end of a meeting with the mayors of Lisbon, Sintra, Amadora, Odivelas and Loures, the Prime Minister, António Costa, announced that the core of the problem of new Covid-19 contagions «focuses on 15 parishes of these councils', which will be subject to new containment measures.  In addition to resetting the maximum limit of 10 people per gathering, the Government will approve a diploma that provides for administrative offenses, with the reinforcement of security forces in the street, allowing "the fine of those who organize or who participate in gatherings that are not allowed" .  The new restrictions will also be approved this Monday in a remote Council of Ministers and will come into effect at 00:00 on Tuesday." (June 23)  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210618161836/https://www.sns.gov.pt/noticias/2020/06/22/covid-19-novas-medidas-aml/

Source: https://archive.vn/JMPoU    "It was one of the first decisions of the Energy Services Regulatory Authority, after a state of emergency was declared in Portugal on March 18: the regulator put forward exceptional conditions for the provision of energy supply services to avoid electricity supply interruptions , natural gas and piped liquefied petroleum gases (LPG) as essential public services. (...) In other words, with the country closed at home, because of the public health crisis caused by the Covid -19 pandemic, no company could cut electricity and gas in case of unpaid bills on the client side. And so it was until June 30, 2020 for electricity consumers at low normal voltage (contracted power up to 41.4 kVA ) and at low pressure (with annual consumption of natural gas up to 10 000m³ ).    Now, since the start of July, the rules have changed again. ERSE reminds that, pursuant to Law No. 18/2020, of May 29, the prohibition of interruption of electricity and natural gas (does not include piped LPG) was extended until September 30 for domestic consumers who are in unemployment situation, loss of household income equal to or greater than 20%, or infection by Covid-19. In all other cases, companies can now cut electricity and gas from this month if bills are not paid." The Council of Ministers approved the continuation of the deconfinement process initiated on April 30, 2020. Notwithstanding the new measures, the Minister of State and Presidency, Mariana Vieira da Silva, underlined the importance of maintaining the rules for limiting crowds – 20 or 10 people, according to the situation (contingency or alert) - should be followed. "The Council of Ministers approved the resolution that extends the declaration of the contingency situation in the Lisbon Metropolitan Area (AML), and of alert in the rest of the territory, until the end of August 2020, due to the Covid-19 pandemic     (...) mainland Portugal (with the exception of AML) will remain in a state of alert, with the following restrictions in force:    (...) Retail and service establishments may open before 10:00 am;  Maintenance of restaurant operating rules, with the possibility of public access for new admissions until midnight, with establishments closing at 1:00 am.  Bars, other drinking establishments without shows and drinking establishments with a dance space remain closed, although they can function as cafes or pastry shops (...) if these comply with the rules of the General Directorate of Health (...)  Public services will preferablly maintain face-to-face service by appointment (...)     The AML (...) will remain in state of contingency and with more restrictive containment measures:    (...) Prohibition of the sale of alcoholic beverages in service areas and gas stations;  Opening hours of commercial establishments can be changed by decision of the mayors of the municipalities, the mandatory opening at 10:00 am and closing at 8:00 pm is no longer in force;  No closing time is imposed for fuel supply services (they can operate 24 hours a day exclusively for the sale of fuel), pharmacies, funeral homes, sports facilities, clinics, offices and veterinarians." September 10 - "The Prime Minister, António Costa, today presented the measures that will be applied from 15 September, the day on which mainland Portugal will enter into a contingency situation to face the Covid-19 pandemic.  At the press conference after the Council of Ministers meeting, António Costa underlined that the measures presented are aimed at preventing an exponential increase in contagion with the gradual resumption of activity.  (...) Measures for mainland Portugal  Commercial establishments cannot open before 10am (with exceptions); Closing hours for establishments between 8 pm and 11 pm, by municipal decision; In shopping center catering areas, maximum limit of 4 people per group; Prohibition on the sale of alcoholic beverages at service stations and, from 8 pm, in all establishments (except meals); Prohibition of consumption of alcoholic beverages on public roads; (...) In restaurants, cafes and patisseries 300m from schools, maximum limit of 4 people per group;  Measures for the Lisbon and Porto metropolitan areas  Mirror teams: Rotation scales between telework and face-to-face work; Mandatory time offset: Different entry and exit times; Different times for breaks and meals; Reduce commuting."   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201018213429/https://www.sns.gov.pt/noticias/2020/09/10/covid-19-situacao-de-contingencia/

On September 15, Portugal has entered into a state of contingency "in what the Prime Minister António Costa calls a “new phase”, and with that comes new measures to avoid the spread of the virus. Among the first measures adopted by the government, announced this Thursday, "are the reduction of the limit of people in gatherings as well as the number of people seated per table in restaurants.  After a Council of Ministers meeting, António Costa announced to the country what will change in the coming days. The main measures announced include a limitation of gatherings (up 10 people). "Flights to and from Portugal  Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to:  - European Union countries;  - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland – and the United Kingdom;  - Australia, Canada, China, South Korea, Georgia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay.  It is not necessary to present the COVID-19 Test on these flights, unless the destinations are the archipelagos of Madeira or the Azores.    Flights between Portugal and other destinations will only be permitted for essential travel. In this case, passengers must present a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before departure time. This test is not asked in Portugal for those who are in transit and do not have to leave the airport facilities.  “Essential travel” is defined as trips allowing the transit, entry into and departure from Portugal for the following persons:  - citizens of a European Union member state, Schengen Associated countries and their family members;  - citizens repatriated through consular assistance;  - third-country nationals travelling for professional purposes, study, family reunions, health and humanitarian reasons and under the reciprocity principle.  In essential travels, national and foreign citizens with legal residence in Portugal and also diplomatic personnel accredited in Portugal who, exceptionally, do not present the test, will have to do it on arrival, at the airport, and at their own expense. Foreign passengers who embark without the test performed, will be refused entry into national territory, with the airline being the subject of a fine."    Source: Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201015211126/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/node/421175

The Portuguese government has approved a moratorium on bank loan repayments for families and companies affected by the coronavirus outbreak and a recent extension until end-September 2021.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201105150539/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    “Although the Parliament has extended until December 31, 2020 protection for tenants whose tenancy contracts are coming to an end, they can even be evicted if they fail to pay their rent - and missing a single month will be enough reason for having to leave the house. The objective is also to protect the owners, in cases when individuals do not leave the house, but also do not pay the rent. The rule is enshrined in the law approved in the Assembly of the Republic last Friday, September 25, 2020, which extends the aforementioned protection until the end of the year, as part of the measures implemented to mitigate the effects of the Covid pandemic -19 (…)”    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210622005807/https://www.idealista.pt/news/imobiliario/habitacao/2020/09/30/44764-inquilinos-com-contratos-a-chegar-ao-fim-podem-mesmo-ser-despejados-caso-falhem    30/9- From this Wednesday, the Portuguese may suffer the cut of essential services such as electricity or water, if they do not pay the monthly bill. Until now, due to the pandemic, companies were prohibited from making this cut, even if consumers had debts. This rule has no exceptions, meaning that it those who are unemployed, in isolation after being diagnosed with COVID-19 or whose household suffered a reduction of income of 20% or more are now required to pay, unlike what happened until now. From now on, the only solution will be to ask to pay the debt in instalments.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205225508/https://tvi24.iol.pt/aominuto/5e56645d0cf2071930699ff6/covid-19-empresas-ja-podem-cortar-agua-e-luz-por-dividas/5f7487240cf2649b90455c86    Note: Code subject to interpretation since in the last two measures (payment of bills in instalments + prevention of evictions in certain cases) the government is not exactly freezing financial obligations (however, since there is a wide range of relief available, if fits the 2 coding).

October 8 - "The second phase of the preventive testing program for the SARS-CoV 2 virus in nursing homes and residential homes starts this week, gradually, in each of the five regions of the continental territory, with the objective of identifying positive employees and controlling the spread of the infection. Progressively, all districts in the country will be covered.  In the new phase of this Program, employees of homes with 50 or more users will be tested preventively. In the districts of Lisbon and Porto, as they are urban areas with greater epidemiological risk, homes with a capacity equal to or greater than 30 users will be tested. This criterion may be changed if there are outbreaks in the community.  Each residential structure will be subject to regular testing, which will be phased in by groups of employees, which allows for signaling the highest risk situations. Testing is expected to take 5 to 6 months (...) Preventive testing in homes is one of the measures that is part of the MTSSS's integrated program to support homes. In addition to this testing plan, the COVID Lares Line was launched on October 2, which guarantees, through the number 707 20 70 70, permanent monitoring of these institutions, monitoring and responding to their needs."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210626125940/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/comunicado?i=nova-fase-de-testes-preventivos-em-lares-arranca-esta-semana

"The measures approved on October 14 remain in effect for the continental national territory:    . Raise the alert level to the situation of calamity;  . Gatherings are limited to 5 persons, in public spaces and in commercial establishments and services.  . Family events, such as baptisms and weddings, are limited to 50 persons.  . Prohibition of academic events such as parties, including reception practices for new students.  . Reinforcement of monitoring and inspection of compliance by the competent authorities.  . Increase of the maximum fine for non-compliance to € 10,000 (businesses).     In addition to these, the following remain in force:    . Prohibition of selling alcoholic beverages at service stations or at gas stations and at supermarkets and hypermarkets, after 20:00;  . Prohibition of selling alcoholic beverages in restaurants destined for consumption outside the establishment or for home delivery;  . Prohibition of the consumption of alcoholic beverages on public roads and outside spaces of restaurants and bars after 20:00, except in the context of meal service;  . Restriction of the maximum capacity in commercial establishments of 1 person per 13 square meters, to avoid concentration of people at the door;  . Restriction of the opening hours of commercial and service provision establishments, with the exception, for example, of pastry shops, cafés, hairdressers or gyms:        - opening hours only after 10:00;       - closing hours between 20:00 and 23:00;  These schedules may be adapted by the municipality with territorial authority, subject to a favorable opinion from the local health authority and the security forces.  . Recommendations of social distance and hands’ hygiene."    "Bars and Nightclubs remain closed and may operate only as cafes or pastries and are subject to the rules specified for these establishments." "The elderly who are in care homes can receive more than one visit per week, according to the Directorate-General for Health (DGS) (...) each local health authority may suspend or restrict visits, according to the evolution of the epidemiological situation (...) Visits to care homes were suspended across the country between March 13 and May 18, when they were resumed in all units, but initially only one per user and only once a week.    (...) The Directorate General of Health recalls that visits to residential structures for the elderly, to the Integrated Continuing Care Units (UCCI), the National Network of Continuing Integrated Care (RNCCI), and to Social Support Establishments for Children, Young Elderly People or People with Disabilities should take place only by appointment, with limited duration and in a ventilated area. Visitors are not allowed to take personal items or food.    In the information, the DGS says that the institution "must have a plan for operationalizing the visits and have identified a professional responsible for the process", which must always follow the social distancing requirements, use masks and disinfect their hands. The space must be sanitized between visits and people with signs or symptoms suggestive of covid-19 or with contact with a suspected or confirmed case of the disease in the last 14 days should not make or receive visits.    "The institution must ensure that the visit takes place in its own space, spacious and with ventilation conditions (ideally, outdoor space), and visits should not be carried out in the user's living room or in the bedroom itself, except in cases where the user is find bedridden”, he recalls, stressing that in the case of shared rooms, conditions of physical separation will have to be created.    The DGS recalls that the institution must, whenever possible, define corridors and circulation doors only for visits, different from those used by users and professionals, that the maximum number of one visitor per resident must be respected and that visitors do not they must circulate through the space or use the users' sanitary facilities.    "If this is not possible, a sanitary installation must be defined for the exclusive use of visitors during the period of visits, which must be sanitized, between visits and before being used again by users", he adds.    The DGS also recalls that the period of visits must not exceed 90 minutes and that visitors who test positive for the new coronavirus must inform the local health authority, “if they have visited the institution within 48 hours before the onset of symptoms”.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210626124304/https://www.sns.gov.pt/noticias/2020/10/19/covid-19-visitas-aos-lares/    October 8 - "The second phase of the preventive testing program for the SARS-CoV 2 virus in nursing homes and residential homes starts this week, gradually, in each of the five regions of the continental territory, with the objective of identifying positive employees and controlling the spread of the infection. Progressively, all districts in the country will be covered.    In the new phase of this Program, employees of homes with 50 or more users will be tested preventively. In the districts of Lisbon and Porto, as they are urban areas with greater epidemiological risk, homes with a capacity equal to or greater than 30 users will be tested. This criterion may be changed if there are outbreaks in the community.    Each residential structure will be subject to regular testing, which will be phased in by groups of employees, which allows for signaling the highest risk situations. Testing is expected to take 5 to 6 months (...) Preventive testing in homes is one of the measures that is part of the MTSSS's integrated program to support homes. In addition to this testing plan, the COVID Lares Line was launched on October 2, which guarantees, through the number 707 20 70 70, permanent monitoring of these institutions, monitoring and responding to their needs."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210626125940/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/comunicado?i=nova-fase-de-testes-preventivos-em-lares-arranca-esta-semana    Note: Code remains unchanged since, even though elderly living in care homes or similar facilities are allowed to receive more than one visitor per week, there are still substantial limits (e.g. only one visitor at a time for 90 min and those who have had symptoms in the last 2 weeks are not allow), visits are only allowed if done in specific places (e.g. outside, ventilated spaces) and preventive testing is still ongoing.

The F1 Grand Prix started on Friday, October 23 and end on Sunday, October 25, in Portimão (Algarve). The Grand Prix racing returned to Portugal for the first time in 24 years - the last time Formula 1 passed through Portugal was in 1996, in Estoril. Given the sanitary conditions due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the AIA's capacity was of the Autódromo Internacional do Algarve (AIA) was reduced to 27,500 seats, according to the recommendations of the Directorate-General of Health (DGS).     "The images from the stands of the Formula 1 Grand Prix in Portugal are generating outrage, especially on social networks, due to the lack of distance between the public (...) some of the spectators were seen to breach the recommended social distance and without wearing face protection masks against Covid-19."    (Given that this event was only an exception and that all public events in the country are still cancelled this indicator was coded as 2G)    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201029163929/https://www.time24.news/2020/10/f1-in-portugal-the-images-that-are-generating-outrage-on-social-networks.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20201029163726/https://observador.pt/2020/10/24/formula-1-quem-nao-cumprir-distanciamento-sera-expulso-do-autodromo-de-portimao/

Portugal's parliament on Friday passed a bill which imposed the mandatory use of a mask on the street and public spaces in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus.    The order was passed a day after authorities reported 3,270 new coronavirus cases, the highest single-day increase since the beginning of the pandemic. It will be in effect for at least 70 days.    The use of a mask is compulsory for all people "over ten years old to access, circulate or stay in public spaces and roads whenever the physical distance recommended by health authorities are impossible", according to the bill.    The obligation between "people from the same household, when they are not in the proximity of third parties" can be waived or by means of a "medical certificate" that the clinical condition or cognitive impairment does not allow the use of masks.    It is also not mandatory to wear a mask when "it is incompatible with the nature of the activities that people are carrying out."    Those who violate the order face fines of between 100 euros ($118) and 500 euros ($590). Other items such as visors will not be acceptable as substitutes.    The order will be reassessed following the expiry of the mandated period with a renewal a possibility."    These rules will be applied from Wednesday, October 28."    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201028100351/https://newsaf.cgtn.com/news/2020-10-24/Portugal-s-Parliament-approves-mandatory-use-of-masks-in-outdoor-areas-UPMSI69oJy/index.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028100922/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2020-10-27-A-partir-de-quarta-feira-vai-ter-de-usar-mascara-na-rua

"Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to:  - European Union countries;  - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland – and the United Kingdom;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.  It is not necessary to present the COVID-19 Test on these flights, unless the destinations are the archipelagos of Madeira or the Azores.    Flights between Portugal and other destinations will only be permitted for essential travel. In this case, passengers must present a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before departure time. This test is not asked in Portugal for those who are in transit and do not have to leave the airport facilities.  “Essential travel” is defined as trips allowing the transit, entry into and departure from Portugal for the following persons:  - citizens of a European Union member state, Schengen Associated countries and their family members;  - citizens repatriated through consular assistance;  - third-country nationals travelling for professional purposes, study, family reunions, health and humanitarian reasons and under the reciprocity principle.  In essential travels, national and foreign citizens with legal residence in Portugal and also diplomatic personnel accredited in Portugal who, exceptionally, do not present the test, will have to do it on arrival, at the airport, and at their own expense. Foreign passengers who embark without the test performed, will be refused entry into national territory, with the airline being the subject of a fine."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123150158/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/node/421175%C2%A0

"Lisbon, Nov. 9, 2020 (Lusa) Portugal on Monday entered a state of emergency to last until 23 November as part of the effort to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, with the imposition among other measures of an overnight curfew in 121 municipalities deemed to be most at risk in terms of new infections.  The curfew, under which residents must on weekdays be off the streets from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. and on the next two weekends from 1 p.m. to 5 a.m., is in force in municipalities that together have 70% of Portugal's population, including all those in the Lisbon and Porto Metropolitan Areas.  The measure, which was approved by the cabinet at an extraordinary meeting on Saturday evening, foresees exceptions such as journeys to work or to return home, emergency situations, a daily walk in the vicinity of home, or taking a pet for a walk."  Note: These measures are in place only in some municipalities in mainland Portugal hence the T flag.  Source: https://archive.vn/PI5M8

Everyone can take a rapid test, however, it is recommended that it is taken in cases when individuals present symptoms or have a condition susceptible to hospitalization. The Directorate General of Health (DGS) clarifies that rapid antigen tests should be seen as an alternative to molecular PCR tests or as a second line of diagnosis, depending on the clinical and epidemiological context of the patient/individual, the availability of molecular PCR tests and the timely response capacity. The DGS "does not recommend its widespread use, but its proper use", according to the guidelines that enter into force on 9 November. If the test result is positive, the patient should be referred to the National Health Service; if negative, a molecular test should be performed within the next 24 hours in case there is a high probability of infection.  Source: https://archive.vn/6QbnC

The State of Emergency by the President of the Republic, comes into force at 00h00 of 24 November.    "Extremely high risk" and "very high risk" counties:  - On business days, commercial establishments must close until 22:00. Restaurants, cultural facilities and sports facilities must close until 22:30 (catering establishments can operate until 01:00, but only for home deliveries).  - On weekends and holidays, commercial establishments can only operate between 08:00 and 13:00. - - The catering can work after that time, but only for 'take-away' and home deliveries.    "High risk" counties:  - Commercial establishments must close until 22:00. Restaurants, cultural facilities and sports facilities must close until 22:30 (catering establishments can operate until 01:00, but only for home deliveries).    "Moderate risk" counties  - Commercial establishments cannot open before 10:00 am, with the exception of hairdressers, barbers, beauty salons, restaurants and the like, cafeterias, tea houses and the like, driving schools and technical vehicle inspection centers, as well as gyms and gyms.  - Most commercial establishments are closed between 8 pm and 11 pm, and the closing time, within this interval, as well as the opening time, may be fixed by the mayors of the city councils, subject to a favorable opinion from the local health authority and security forces.  - Restaurants have to close at 1:00 am (with new admissions until midnight), with their capacity limited to 50% of capacity.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221101820/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/new-state-of-emergency-measures/    Bars and Nightclubs remain closed countrywide and may operate only as cafes or pastries and are subject to the rules specified for these establishments. The 2021 state budget adopted on November 26 foresees further support to the national health system, employment and incomes of households and firms. Key measures include:   (i) income support measures, such as temporary reduction of PIT withholdings (0.1 percent of GDP);   (ii) expanded subsidy for employment and resumption of activity (0.5 percent of GDP) and extended support for workers' lost income and coverage for those without access to unemployment protection (0.2 percent of GDP);   (iii) staff reinforcement in the civil service, particularly in health and education (0.1 percent of GDP) and an extraordinary risk subsidy in the amount of 20 percent of base salary for health professionals at the forefront of the response to COVID-19; and   (iv) VAT tax rebate to stimulate consumption in the catering sectors, accommodation and culture by returning the VAT paid on consumption in these sectors (0.1 percent GDP).

Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201205210457/https://www.time24.news/2020/12/covid-19-vaccine-in-portugal-will-be-optional-and-free-arrives-in-early-2021-and-there-will-be-at-least-22-million-doses.html    Link:

The Government presented yesterday, December 3, the Vaccination Plan against Covid-19. According to the document, the vaccine, which should arrive in Portugal as early as January, will be universal, free and optional, and will be made available to the population according to the characteristics approved by the European Medicines Agency. Three phases are planned for the implementation of the vaccination plan against Covid-19 in 2021, which will accompany the pace of availability of vaccines.    1st phase - It is intended for people over 50 with associated pathologies; residents and professionals in nursing homes and long-term care units; Health professionals; armed forces, security forces and critical services professionals. At this stage, approximately 950 thousand people should be vaccinated.    2nd phase - In this phase 1.8 million people over 65 years of age and around 900 thousand with associated pathologies and over 50 years will be vaccinated.    3rd phase - The rest of the population. The groups in this phase will be reviewed according to the pace of delivery of the vaccines    Vaccine administration  The first phase of vaccination will be administered at the approximately 1,200 vaccination points that are usual in health centers, in homes and long-term care units.  The health centers will be destined to 400 thousand people over 50 years old and associated comorbidities, while users and home professionals will be vaccinated there by the resident nursing teams.  The vaccine will also be administered to health professionals and essential services in the field of occupational medicine.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213003729/https://www.sns.gov.pt/noticias/2020/12/04/plano-de-vacinacao-contra-a-covid-19/

"The Government approved a diploma that follows the rule of the State budget that provides that the mechanisms for reducing or suspending workers' contracts - the so-called lay-off, which currently has three versions - no longer imply wage cuts, passing the maturity to be guaranteed to 100%.    However, according to the press release following the Council of Ministers, in the case of the classic lay-off of the Labor Code, which has existed for several decades, wage cuts of one third of the salary continue to apply if the lay-off has started before 1 January 2021.     "It is established that all workers who are covered by the simplified lay-off, lay-off of the Labor Code (motivated by the Covid-19 disease pandemic and which begins after January 1, 2021) and extraordinary support for the progressive resumption of activity will receive 100% of their normal gross remuneration up to 3 Minimum Guaranteed Monthly Remuneration (RMMG) ", that is, 1,995 euros," with no additional effort by employers ", indicates the Government in the statement of the Council of Ministers .    Thus, a lay-off that started in October, for example, and continues until March 2021, will not be covered by the 100% payment guarantee."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130171645/https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/detalhe/governo-aprova-lay-off-com-salarios-pagos-a-100-mas-abre-excecoes    Example (for cases in which employees only receive 2/3 of their salary): "workers with a suspended contract, Social Security pays 70% of the salary and the employer is responsible for 30%, of two thirds of the remuneration (66%). For example, in a gross salary of € 1,000, where the worker receives € 666.67 (net salary), the employer is responsible for paying € 200 and Social Security contributes € 466.67" (less than 50%).    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210316064314/https://rr.sapo.pt/2020/03/30/economia/calculadoras-lay-off-quanto-paga-uma-empresa-a-trabalhadores-com-contrato-suspenso-ou-horario-reduzido/noticia/187229/    Note: Since the fully paid lay-off (100%) only applies to those who make the request AFTER January 1 the code remains unchanged - in the other cases the government is replacing less than 50% of lost salary.

"in November last year the Government (...) approved the ban on the suspension of essential services such water, electricity or gas during the first half of 2021, for those who are unemployed, have had a reduction in household income equal to or greater than 20%, or have been infected by Covid-19." This suspension will remain in place until at least June 30, 2021. This exceptional regime, was implemented early in the pandemic, in March 2020. At first, the suspension was determined until September 30th, after which the deadline was extended until the end of the year.    Source: https://archive.vn/7dJwA

If all goes according to plan (meaning the Pfizer vaccination gets European Medicine Agency approval later this month), Phase One will start in January immunising:    People over the age of 50 with at least one of the following pathologies: cardiac insufficiency, heart disease, renal insufficiency or chronic respiratory disease requiring ventilation.  Residents of old people’s homes and those interned in professional continuous care facilities  Healthcare professionals directly involved in caring for the sick, Armed Forces personnel, security forces and all ‘essential service personnel’ (criteria still to be defined).    Code remains the same as this extra clause for clinically vulnerable has not yet been bought into effect    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111141448/https://www.portugalresident.com/portugals-vaccination-programme-opens-with-950000-getting-shots-between-january-and-february/

“(…) This Thursday, the Council of Ministers confirmed the new confinement, restoring the duty of home collection and determining the closure of a series of activities. Businesses in these sectors will have, according to the Prime Minister, automatic access to the simplified lay-off (…) It should be noted that, since the beginning of July, the legislation dictates that only companies closed by legal or administrative imposition can access the extraordinary instrument in question. This condition meant that, in recent months, employers in crisis had to resort to alternative regimes, such as support for the progressive recovery (designed exactly to follow the simplified lay-off ).     (...) the Prime Minister made it clear that companies that want to remain in support of the progressive recovery can do so, now it remains to consider which of the options more advantageous .    The simplified lay-off is an exceptional financial support intended exclusively for the payment of remuneration, in periods of reduced working hours or suspension of employment contracts.  The support for progressive recovery is a support payment of wages only in periods of reduced hours work , that is, this scheme cannot suspend the labor contracts, although it is possible to reduce to 100% the normal period of work. It is important to point out, however, that in the simplified lay-off, employers can freely choose which cut to apply in the schedules or suspend contracts, while in support of the progressive resumption this decision is conditioned to the break in billing. For example, companies with cuts of at least 75% are the only ones that can reduce hours by 100%. And companies with cuts below 40% can only cut schedules by 33%. Companies with reductions of at least 40%, but less than 60%, can reduce the hours by 40% maximum. (…) The support for the progressive recovery is available to all employers with cuts of at least 25%.     (…) the Council of Ministers recently approved a diploma that determines that, both in the simplified lay-off and in the support of the progressive resumption , workers are entitled to 100% of their remuneration, up to 1,995 euros (three times the value of the national minimum wage), at no additional cost to the employer, compared to what has been required so far.    However, there are important differences in this payment to highlight. In the simplified lay-off, the employer is responsible for paying the hours worked, as well as 30% of the amount needed to, together with the first slice of remuneration, make up two thirds of the normal salary. In support of the progressive recovery , there are more nuances to take into account. In this regime, the employer also has to pay 100% of the hours worked, unless there are reductions equal to or greater than 75% . If so, employees can receive from Social Security a support equivalent to 35% of the salary for the hours worked.    There is also a difference from the simplified lay-off in compensation for hours not worked. In support of the gradual recovery, employers pay 30% of 80% of the compensation for hours not worked, with Social Security bearing the cost of the remaining amount (70%). In the event that the company chooses to cut working hours by more than 60% (which can only be done by employers who have reductions of at least 75%), the aforementioned compensation for unworked hours is ensured in full by Social Security .     (…) With regards to social contributions , the simplified lay-off (…) provides for the total exemption of all companies that adhere to this regime. In support of the progressive recovery, a 50% discount is foreseen, but only for micro, small and medium-sized companies and only with regard to compensation for hours not worked. Large companies pay must continue paying the social contributions of the workers, in both schemes.    In which scheme does the employee receives more?    If a worker who receives, for example, one thousand gross euros per month, under normal conditions, sees his contract suspended , under the simplified lay-off , he is entitled to earn, as of January 2021, the totality of that amount , which represents an expense of 200 euros for the company. In this situation, the employer is responsible for ensuring 30% of two thirds of those thousand euros (the 200 euros), while Social Security transfers the missing amount (800 euros) to the company. In this case, there is no place for social contributions, so the total expense of the employer is equivalent 200 euros .    (...) the simplified lay-off is preferable, but if the company that opted for supporting the progressive recovery is micro, small or medium size, this second regime will be the most advantageous . This is because, in support of the progressive recovery, these employers are entitled to a 50% discount on social contributions, which means that the expense for the job in question would rise to 118.75 euros , below the 200 euros of lay- simplified off .    What if the employer chooses to have workers work for a few hours ? (…) If the referred worker with a salary of one thousand euros sees his schedule reduced by 50% , he is entitled, in both regimes, to one thousand euros of salary.    In the simplified lay-off , this amount is the result of the sum of 500 euros paid by the employer for the hours worked, with 50 euros paid by the company for the hours not worked, with the remaining 450 euros paid by the Social Security. In total, the employees spends 550 euros for this employer, since he does not have to pay social contributions.    In support of the recovery, the 1000€ euros result from the sum of 500 euros paid for the hours worked (insured in full by the employer or in 65%, if there are reductions of at least 75%) with 500 euros paid for the hours not worked. , of which 120 euros insured by the employer (equivalent to 30% of 80% of hours not worked) and 380 euros supported by Social Security. The cost of the job for the employer is 857.5 euros (or 682.5 euros, if there is help for the hours worked), since the above mentioned expenses include social contributions.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210320020438/https://eco.sapo.pt/2021/01/14/lay-off-simplificado-esta-de-volta-e-mais-vantajoso-que-o-apoio-a-retoma/    Note: Policy coded on January 15 since the confinement started on this date - see C2 for additional information. These new measures are in some aspects unclear and, therefore, the code can be subject to interpretation. Selected 1 also because for e.g. in the culture sector the measures differ - the amount is lower than half of the median wage 438€ vs 1.1314€ - Source:http://web.archive.org/web/20210320024454/https://observador.pt/2021/02/11/em-ano-de-pandemia-o-salario-medio-em-portugal-subiu-29-para-1-314-euros/)

The country entered the new confinement after midnight on Friday, January 15. The measures essentially focused on the compulsory home collection and the physical closure of commercial establishments considered non-essential.    However, the number of infected people in Portugal continues to grow and the Prime Minister António Costa announced new containment measures - that will come into force on January 20 -  in an attempt to halt the exponential growth of the pandemic. The ADDITIONAL measures announced include (see previous note):    - The sale or delivery of products to the wicket is prohibited in any establishment of the non-food business, such as clothing;  - Prohibited the sale or delivery of products of any type of drinks, such as coffee, in food establishments that are authorized to practice take-away;  - All dining spaces in shopping centers must close, even for take-away;  - Senior Universities, Day Centers and Community Centers are required to close;  - All workers who have to travel to provide face-to-face work, need a credential issued by their employer;  - All service companies with more than 250 workers must, within the next 48 hours, send to the authority for working conditions, the nominal list of all workers whose face-to-face work they consider indispensable;  - All establishments of any nature must close at 8 pm on working days and at 1 pm on weekends, with the exception of the food retail which may be open until 5 pm on weekends.    Source: https://archive.vn/Lezq6

The government   (i) reinstated a job-retention program (simplified layoff) (which had expired in September of 2020) for businesses that were required to close   (ii) introduced support towards the progressive resumption of activity offered to firms with a reduction in turnover of at least 25%.   (iii) Changes were also made to the existing Apoiar.pt programs and the eligibility criteria, such as extending the turnover drop period, easing equity capital requirements, and introducing the possibility of submitting applications by companies with debts to the tax administration and social security.   (iv)  considering a recapitalization program for firms.    After having extended the exceptional regime for the granting of interest-free loans by the Institute of Housing and Urban Rehabilitation (IHRU) to support the payment of rents until 1 July 2021, the Government has now released the ordinance regulating its concession.   - A drop in income of more than 20% of the household remains necessary, but the required effort rate is reduced from 35% to 30%, thus widening the range of beneficiaries.   - At the end of the loan, borrowers can request the conversion of the loan into a non-repayable loan, which may reach 100% conversion, in which case no future reimbursement to IHRU is necessary. An option that depends on the effort rate and is aimed at low-income tenants, being the option valid for all loans granted since April 2020.   - guarantee of granting loans to new contracts and maintaining the status of borrower in the case of contract renewals and new contracts, whenever it does not result in an increase in income or, even if the increase occurs, always there is a reason for this, namely increase in the household or non-renewal of the previous contract, as opposed to the landlord. "The Directorate-General for Health (DGS) published this Friday an update of Standard 019/2020 on the National Testing Strategy for SARS-CoV-2 and Standard 015/2020 on Contact Screening. These updates, which take effect at 00.00 on February 15, intensify the testing strategy to control the COVID-19 pandemic, extending the use of rapid antigen testing in Portugal.  In the current epidemiological context, all people continue to be tested as soon as they develop suspected symptoms of COVID-19 and all high-risk and low-risk contacts of a confirmed case. Confirmed case contacts should be tested with molecular tests (PCR) (...)  For the control of community transmission, regular laboratory screenings are recommended in municipalities with a cumulative incidence of 14 days exceeding 480/100,000 inhabitants in secondary schools for students, teaching and non-teaching staff; in prisons for prisoners and professionals; and in occupational contexts of high social exposure (namely factories, construction, among others) to their professionals. In these situations, rapid lateral flow test, should be used every 14 days."  Source: https://archive.ph/rvoRF

Phase 1  From December 2020:  - Health professionals involved in patient care  - Professionals in the armed forces, security forces and critical services  - Professionals and residents in Residential Structures for the Elderly (ERPI) and similar institutions  - Professionals and users of the National Integrated Continuing Care Network (RNCCI).  From February 2021 :  - People aged =50 years, with at least one of the following pathologies: Cardiac insufficiency, Coronary heart disease, Renal insufficiency or chronic respiratory disease under ventilatory support and / or long-term oxygen therapy  - People aged 80 and over.    Vaccines: The covid-19 vaccines that Portugal purchased are, according to Infarmed, as follows: 6.9 million doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine, 4.5 million from Johnson & Johnson, 4.5 million from Pfizer, 4/5 million from CureVac, 1.8 million from Moderna and number of doses to be determined from the Sanofi-GSK vaccine.    Feb 19 - If in the early days orders arrived more widely, since there was only one type of vaccine approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA), that of Pfizer, in recent weeks they have arrived more frequently, given that in addition to the aforementioned company, there are two other different types of vaccines approved in the European Union: the Moderna vaccine, approved on 6 January, and the AstaZeneca / Oxford, approved on 29 January.    Link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210220113020/https://covid19.min-saude.pt/vacinacao/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210220113620/https://eco.sapo.pt/2021/02/19/portugal-garante-quase-um-terco-do-previsto-para-este-trimestre-com-novo-lote-de-vacinas-da-astrazeneca/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210220113558/https://tvi24.iol.pt/aominuto/5e56645d0cf2071930699ff6/estas-sao-as-vacinas-que-portugal-comprou/5fc90ee90cf2c78555546d99  https://web.archive.org/web/20210220113620/https://eco.sapo.pt/2021/02/19/portugal-garante-quase-um-terco-do-previsto-para-este-trimestre-com-novo-lote-de-vacinas-da-astrazeneca/

The Directorate-General for Health (DGS) published this Friday an update of Standard 019/2020 on the National Testing Strategy for SARS-CoV-2 and Standard 015/2020 on Contact Screening. These updates, which take effect at 00.00 on February 15, intensify the testing strategy to control the COVID-19 pandemic, extending the use of rapid antigen testing in Portugal.  In institutions supporting  the most vulnerable populations, including the elderly, periodic screenings should be carried out of residents, users and professionals, of 14/14 days, using rapid tests.  Source: https://archive.ph/rvoRF

Feb 18 - The Council of Ministers approved the decree-law that extends the exceptional support to the family in the scope of the suspension of classroom and non-classroom activities. Exceptional support to the family is extended to workers who are engaged in teleworking and choose to stop their activity to provide assistance to the family, in the following situations:   - single-parent family, during the custody period of the child or other dependent;   - the household includes at least one child or other dependent who is attending social equipment to support early childhood, a pre-school or primary school;   - the household includes at least one dependent with a disability, with a proven disability equal to or greater than 60%, regardless of age.  As a public policy measure that aims to protect the family's income and promote a balance in the provision of assistance to the family, the value of the support is increased when it is alternated weekly between the parents or if it is a single-parent family, with Social Security assuming a differential of up to 100%.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210220191220/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/noticia?i=pais-em-teletrabalho-vao-poder-optar-pela-assistencia-a-familia

"Flights to Portugal  Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to:  - European Union countries;  - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.    (...) Flights from the United Kingdom and from Brazil  All commercial or private flights between Portugal and the United Kingdom and between Portugal and Brazil are suspended. Except for the right of entry for national citizens and their families and holders of residence permits in Portugal, only on flights of a humanitarian nature for the purpose of repatriation of those citizens. These passengers will have to present, at the time of departure, proof of a RT-PCR test with a negative result, carried out within 72 hours prior to departure time. Upon arriving in the national territory, they must comply with a period of 14 days of quarantine at home, or in a place indicated by the health authorities.    Flights between Portugal and other destinations will only be permitted for essential travel (from and to non-EU countries or which are not Schengen Associated Countries). In this case, passengers must present a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before departure time."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210226223703/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

"Portugal halved testing for covid-19 during the new confinement period (...) The European Center for Disease Control and Prevention (ECDC) released this Thursday the list in the EU (which also includes Norway and Iceland) between weeks 3 and 6 of 2021.    The data analyzed reveal that the Government is not fulfilling its promise to increase the number of tests for covid-19. In fact, the number of tests has been declining over the past month. In the last four weeks alone, the testing rate in Portugal has dropped from 4,300 tests per 100,000 inhabitants to 2,100 per 100,000 inhabitants.    These figures translate into a difference of minus 232,751 tests with covid-19 over the last month. The rate of positivity has also dropped considerably.    Part of the decrease in testing for covid-19 in Portugal may be related to the new widespread confinement, since the large part of the population remains at home. It should also be noted that the rule that extends the testing of SARS-CoV-2 to all contacts in Portugal, including the performance of molecular tests to low risk “at the time of identification” of the contact, was published on February 12 by the Portuguese General Directorate of Health (DGS).    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210220065320/https://tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade/ecdc/covid-19-portugal-reduziu-a-testagem-para-metade-durante-novo-confinamento    "Hospital da Luz Lisboa now has a Covid-19 Drive Thru Test available (...) medical prescription is not required".    Source: https://archive.vn/csrQg    Note: The code can be subjected to interpretation: drive-thrus are available everywhere - these were available even prior to the confinement for those who wanted to get tested (e.g. travel)-, however, the number of tests have been decreasing (due to the confinement - since most people stay at home - and the significant reduction in cases). No evidence that there is a lack of tests available was found.

The new diploma determines that the use of a mask is mandatory for those aged 10 or older for access, circulation or permanence in public spaces and roads "whenever physical distance recommended by health authorities is not possible".    This obligation may be waived "in case people belong to the same household and are not in the proximity of third parties" or by presenting a medical certificate or statement attesting that the clinical condition or cognitive impairment of the individual does not allow the use of masks. Portugal has announced that it is suspending the inoculation of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine as a “precaution,” joining other European countries – including France, Germany, Italy and Spain – in halting its use following reports of blood clots post inoculation.    “Portuguese health authorities today decided to suspend the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine against Covid-19 for reasons of precaution and public health,” Portugal’s national health authority said Monday in a statement.     According to the national health authority, the decision was taken “due to reports of the appearance of blood clots in vaccinated people.”    The decision comes despite assertions from the United Kingdom’s Joint Committee on Vaccinations and Immunizations (JCVI) that the vaccine has been “rigorously tested for safety.”     The European Medicines Agency (EMA) also said Monday that the benefits of the AstraZeneca vaccine outweigh the risks, adding that the number of people developing blood clots after vaccination does not seem to be higher than in the general population.    The agency said it would hold an emergency meeting on Thursday to advise on “any further actions that may need to be taken.”    Note: Despite this suspension, the three priority groups continue to be vaccinated.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210316142901/https://edition.cnn.com/world/live-news/coronavirus-pandemic-vaccine-updates-03-16-21/h_4342ae241ec9a83567b7eabedfc3b111

The measure published on the Spanish Foreign Ministry’s website on Monday March 15th (and that enters in force at 1am March 16) means people crossing the border between the two Iberian nations will only be able to cross through authorised border check spots and during the opening hours established.
