Pingo Doce (supermarket) starts this Wednesday, March 31, the sale of self-tests to Covid-19 in 25 Para Wellness pharmacies in the Lisbon region. As of this Thursday, the sale will be extended to the remaining stores across the country, according to the Jerónimo Martins supermarket chain. According to the statement, the tests will be marketed “in this initial phase” in boxes of 25 tests with a cost per test of 6.79 euros.  As of next week, the sale of these tests is expected to be extended “to all Well Being spaces, including those located inside supermarkets and not just parapharmacies with a service counter “. The test results are obtained within 15 to 30 minutes.  (...) “Well’s starts to make available, starting tomorrow, Thursday, in its physical stores from the north to the south of the country, rapid antigen tests of Roche Diagnósticos, in order to anticipate public health care and help to implement the measures of isolation to contain the transmission of the virus in Portugal, “he said in the statement.  (...) Well’s has 280 stores across the country, most of which “will make the tests available this Thursday, and on Friday all other stores in mainland Portugal will make the test available”, adds the official."  Source: https://archive.vn/fF5uw

"The parliament approved this Wednesday the PSD bill that renews the mandatory use of masks in public spaces for another 70 days , a measure that has been in force in Portugal since 28 October and which would end on 5 April.  (...) In the diploma, the PSD proposes a renewal for 70 days : if the deadline starts counting from next Monday, April 5, this obligation will extend until June 13.  (...) The approved bill prolongs, without changes, the current law, which imposes the mandatory use of masks in public spaces and provides for fines of between 100 and 500 euros for non-compliers .  The diploma determines that the use of a mask ( which cannot be replaced by a visor ) is mandatory for those over ten years of age for access, circulation or permanence in public spaces and roads “whenever the physical distance recommended by health authorities proves to be impractical”.  Sources: https://archive.vn/9G41C#selection-2775.0-2883.188

On April 1st, the Prime Minister announced that the ban of travel between municipalities will come to an end after Easter on Monday, April 5th and that in the next two weeks, no restrictions on internal movement, on weekdays or weekends, is expected.  Source: https://archive.vn/nYQRD

"Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to:  - European Union countries;  - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.  All passengers must present proof of a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before boarding time.    Essential travel is allowed only to passengers coming from countries with an incidence rate of 150 cases or more per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Germany, Austria, Belgium, Croatia, Denmark, Slovakia, Finland, Greece, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Norway, the Netherlands, Romania, Switzerland.    Essential travellers coming from countries with an incidence rate equal or over 500 cases or more per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Cyprus, Slovenia, Estonia, France, Hungary, Italy, Malta, Poland and Sweden – must also comply with a prophylactic isolation period of 14 days, after entering mainland Portugal, at home or in a place indicated by the health authorities. The prophylactic isolation does not apply to passengers travelling on essential trips and whose period of stay in national territory, attested by a return ticket, does not exceed 48 hours.    All commercial or private flights between Portugal and the United Kingdom and between Portugal and Brazil are suspended. Except for the right of entry for national citizens and their families and holders of residence permits in Portugal, only on flights of a humanitarian nature for the purpose of repatriation of the said citizens. These passengers must present, at the time of departure, proof of having performed a RT-PCR test with a negative result, carried out within 72 hours prior to the time of departure. When arriving in the national territory, they must comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a location indicated by the health authorities.    Anyone who is obliged to comply with the 14-day prophylactic isolation in Portugal must register with SEF - Foreigners and Borders Service before entering the country (...)     Passengers on commercial flights from South Africa must present proof of a negative RT-PCR test result, carried out within 72 hours prior to departure time and will have to comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a place indicated by the health authorities. This requirement also applies to flights that have stopped over or transited in countries which air traffic with Portugal is authorised, or to passengers registered as having left South Africa in the 14 days prior to their arrival in Portugal.    Flights between Portugal and other destinations not mentioned are suspended."    Source: https://archive.vn/HNp4O    April 1-The Portuguese Prime-Minister, António Costa, announced that "There is an agreement with the Kingdom of Spain to keep the borders closed - in terms of the land border - in order to avoid an increase in the pandemic and keep the situation under control. The borders will remain closed with the exceptions that have been previously announced”.    Source: https://archive.vn/nYQRD

"(...) in November last year the Government (...) approved the ban on the suspension of essential services such water, electricity or gas during the first half of 2021, for those who are unemployed, have had a reduction in household income equal to or greater than 20%, or have been infected by Covid-19."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210323145814/https://www.dinheirovivo.pt/geral/covid-19-pagamento-faseado-de-energia-limitado-a-faturas-ate-30-de-junho-13409907.html    December 18 - "The Parliament has decided that (...) landlords will not be able to terminate lease agreements, even if the tenancy period has expired, unless there is an agreement with the tenant or the latter fails to pay any rent. This suspension will remain in place until at least June 30, 2021." Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213155040/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#P    The Government will support all families, irrespectively of their income, during the general lockdown (that started on Friday, January 15), by paying 10% of their electricity bills (...) For low income families, the reduction in the electricity bill might reach 40%.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118164726/https://eco.sapo.pt/2021/01/12/governo-apoia-familias-com-cerca-de-10-da-fatura-da-luz/  Note: No changes in the last policy were found but currently, the general duty to stay at home remains in place.

The list of priorities for the second phase of the vaccination plan against covid-19 will be changed, if the proposal of the specialist committee of the Directorate-General for Health (DGS) is approved. The plan is to start vaccinating by age, using the criterion of decreasing age groups, but simultaneously including people with diseases associated with increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19, and without age limit. A new “two-legged strategy that will run in parallel”, the DGS said this Thursday.  (...) In the second phase, which begins after the completion of the vaccination of the priority groups of the first phase, on April 11, as announced by the task force coordinator, this new strategy must be “adjusted in order to vaccinate the largest number of people in the smallest period of time ”and taking into account“ an expected increase in the doses of vaccines available.".  Source: https://archive.vn/QtcHO

The Government decided to move to the second phase of the deconfinment plan starting on Monday, April 5.   Even though the entire continental territory will move to the second phase, there are 19  high risk municipalities since these present more than 120 case per 100 thousand inhabitants in the last 14 days. Following the recommendations of specialists, the Prime Minister, António Costa, announced that a second evaluation will take place in two weeks to assess if these high-risk municipalities will move to the third phase.   In these 19 municipalities, António Costo also requested a reinforcement of the measures to "identify, isolate and trace transmission chains" in order to contain risks.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210408140134/https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/coronavirus/detalhe/desconfinamento-tem-luz-verde-para-avancar-a-partir-de-5-de-abril

"Control of people on the Spanish border has been restored.  Cross-border rail traffic is suspended, except for the transport of goods, as well as river transport between Portugal and Spain, establishing, however, some authorized crossing points at the land border.  - Permanently opened border (24 hours a day): Valença, Vila Verde da Raia, Quintanilha, Vilar Formoso, Caia, Vila Verde de Ficalho and Castro Marim;  - Passage allowed on business days, from 6 am to 8 p.m.: Marvão  - Passage allowed on business days, from 6 am to 9 am / 5 pm to 8 pm: Monção, Melgaço, Ponte da Barca - Madalena, Montalegre, Vinhais;  - Passage allowed on business days, from 7 am to 9 am / 5 pm to 7 pm: Miranda do Douro, Termas de Monfortinho, Mourão and Barrancos;  - Rural route of Rio de Onor: passage allowed on Wednesday and Saturday, between 10am and 12pm.    Citizens who are nationals of or legally reside in Portugal, coming from Brazil and South Africa, as well as from Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Cyprus, Croatia, Slovenia, Estonia, France, Hungary, Netherlands, Poland and Sweden Poland and Sweden, entering Portugal by land must comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a place indicated by the health authorities (...)    (...) Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed for essential travel to:  - Citizens of a European Union member state, Schengen Associated countries and their family members;  - Citizens repatriated through consular assistance;- European Union countries;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.  All passengers must present proof of a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before boarding time.    Essential travel is allowed only to passengers coming from countries with an incidence rate of 150 cases or more per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Germany, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Slovakia, Spain, Greece, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Norway, Romania and Switzerland.    Essential travellers coming from countries with an incidence rate equal or over 500 cases or more per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Bulgaria, Czechia, Cyprus, Croatia, Slovenia, Estonia, France, Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland and Sweden – must also comply with a prophilatic isolation period of 14 days, after entering mainland Portugal, at home or in a place indicated by the health authorities. The prophylactic isolation does not apply to passengers treavelling on essential trips and whose period of stay in national territory, attested by a return ticket, does not exceed 48 hours.    Passengers on commercial flights from South Africa and Brazil must present proof of a negative RT-PCR test result, carried out within 72 hours prior to departure time and will have to comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a place indicated by the health authorities. This requirement also applies to flights that have stopped over or transited in countries which air traffic with Portugal is authorised, or to passengers registered as having left South Africa in the 14 days prior to their arrival in Portugal.    Anyone who is obliged to comply with the 14-day prophylactic isolation in Portugal must register with SEF - Foreigners and Borders Service before entering the country at https://travel.sef.pt.    Flights between Portugal and other destinations not mentioned are suspended."    Source: https://archive.vn/u60yM#selection-1651.0-1775.1

On March 31, "The parliament approved (...) the PSD bill that renews the mandatory use of masks in public spaces for another 70 days , a measure that has been in force in Portugal since 28 October and which would end on 5 April. (...) this obligation will extend until June 13. (...) The approved bill prolongs, without changes, the current law, which imposes the mandatory use of masks in public spaces and provides for fines of between 100 and 500 euros for those who do not comply. The diploma determines that the use of a mask ( which cannot be replaced by a visor) is mandatory for those over ten years of age for access, circulation or permanence in public spaces and roads “whenever the physical distance recommended by health authorities proves to be impractical”. "The prime minister announced this Thursday (April 15) that the deconfinement announced in March remains, which means that secondary schools and higher education establishments will resume face-to-face classes starting on April 19.    Pre-schools and primary schools (1st cycle), as well as day care centers, resumed on-site education on March 15. Middle schools (2nd and 3rd cycles), on the other hand,  reopened on April 5th, which means remote classes in Portugal came to an end.    The educational measures will always be at national level, explained the Prime Minister, António Costa, confirming that secondary schools and higher education institutions will open for face-to-face teaching even in the municipalities that will have to regress or stop in the deconfinement process."    Source: https://archive.vn/VyjPs    "(...) the Minister of Education underlined that all measures are being followed to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus and that the testing and new measures of the Directorate-General for Health bring additional security.    "What we see in our schools is a mechanism that protects students, that protects teaching and non-teaching workers. We see the use of masks (...), the use of alcohol gel, the cleaning of spaces", stressed the minister.    For Tiago Brandão Rodrigues, the testing actions are now "improving the protection of our schools and increasing resilience while mitigating the spread of the virus". The Minister also mentioned the importance of strengthening the DGS protocol, which "now goes further: cohabitants of students who are suspected cases and often also the risk contacts that exist in our schools are also being testing". Ten municipalities, in mainland Portugal, will not be moving to the third phase of the deconfinement plan this Monday, of which four will reverse to the first phase (that was implemented starting March 15). These four municipalities - Moura, Odemira, Portimão e Rio Maior - have registered a COVID-19 incidence rate over 240 case per 100 thousand inhabitants. In these municipalities, travel outside of the municipalities will not be allowed - except in cases predicted by the law (including work-related travel and assistance to family members) - for the next 15 days.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210425202101/https://www.tsf.pt/portugal/sociedade/as-regras-nos-10-concelhos-que-nao-avancam-no-desconfinamento-13585798.html

Asymptomatic people (without symptoms of the disease) or who have not had any exposure to SARS-CoV-2 will also be tested for COVID-19 as part of the plan to promote the operationalization of the testing strategy in Portugal (that was already being implemented and has now been extended). The main objective is to detect possible cases of infection early in various “scenarios” such as mass events, sports clubs and transport."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210421160648/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/20/sociedade/noticia/covid19-pessoas-assintomaticas-exposicao-virus-tambem-vao-testadas-1959360

Starting this Friday, April 23, individuals aged 65 or above (including those without any pre-existing conditions) will be able to chose the date and place of vaccination in the Health Directorate General portal. They will be able to accept the date suggested by the portal, chose another one or stay on the waiting list. Those who register in this portal will have to wait for an SMS that will confirm the date, time and place.     According to the government, 2,015,225 people have already taken the first dose, while 689,329 (representing approximately 7% of the population) already have complete vaccination against the virus SARS-CoV-2. By age group, 91% of the elderly over 80 years old (617,566 people) are already vaccinated with the first dose and 58% (394,186) have already received both doses of the vaccine. In the age group between 65 and 79 years old, 42% (669,263) also received the first dose of the vaccine a percentage that drops to just 4% (59,658) if we consider those who have taken the two doses.    Note: Upgraded to 4 since, according to the codebook "Broad groups may include a large group of adults, for example those aged 50-65". In this case, includes those aged 65-79.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514231120/https://www.jn.pt/nacional/pessoas-com-mais-65-anos-podem-agendar-vacinacao-a-partir-de-hoje-13603627.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210514232113/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/23/sociedade/noticia/65-anos-saiba-agendar-vacinacao-covid19-1959726

On Thursday, Portugal's Prime Minister - António Costa -  announced that most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from Saturday, May 1. The  Prime Minister also announced that the parishes of São Teotónio and Longueira-Almograve would stay in a sanitary fence, due to the high incidence of cases of covid-19, especially among workers in the agricultural sector.   The sanitary fence in two parishes in the municipality of Odemira, district of Beja started at 08:00 this Friday, April 30. Circulation in the public road is not allowed, except in the situations provided for in the diploma published in the Diário da República. These exceptions include: sale and acquisition of essential goods and services in establishments that are open in these parishes; travel to and from work; for health-related reasons; support provision to the elderly, children, dependents and vulnerable individuals.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/ http://web.archive.org/web/20210501180700/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-04-30-Cerca-sanitaria-nas-freguesias-de-Odemira-tem-seis-passagens-f5733df2

On Thursday, Portugal's Prime Minister - António Costa -  announced that most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from Saturday, May 1. The  Prime Minister also announced that the parishes of São Teotónio and Longueira-Almograve would stay in a sanitary fence, due to the high incidence of cases of covid-19, especially among workers in the agricultural sector.   The sanitary fence in two parishes in the municipality of Odemira, district of Beja started at 08:00 this Friday, April 30. Road traffic to and from these two parishes in a sanitary fence in the municipality of Odemira is forbidden, except in the situations provided for in the diploma published in the Diário da República.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/ http://web.archive.org/web/20210501180700/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-04-30-Cerca-sanitaria-nas-freguesias-de-Odemira-tem-seis-passagens-f5733df2

The Health Secreatary of State, António Lacerda Sales, announced that the Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, of the Johnson & Johnson group, will be recommended to people over 50 years old and will start start being administred now.     He added that the ongoing studies and the data that are still being analyzed by the European Medicines Agency can justify the revision of this recommendation at any time. Those who are under 50 can choose to receive the Janssen vaccine, as long as they are informed about the benefits and risks, and expressly give their consent.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173819/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/portugal-recomenda-vacina-da-johnson-para-pessoas-com-mais-de-50-anos--13629866.html

The final phase of easing of lockdown for the majority of Portugal was antecipated 2 days and will now come in to force on Saturday, May 1, with much of the country returning to relative normality.     The advance in the easing of lockdown “applies to most of the continent's territory, it applies to 270 of the 278 counties on mainland Portugal", said António Costa.     Restrictions in place for each of the phases:    First phase of the plan  The restrictions and measures foreseen in the first phase of the easing of lockdown plan will again be applied, starting on Saturday, in Portimão and in the parishes of São Teotónio and Almograve, in the municipality of Odemira.    - The setback implies the closure of terraces, shops up to 200 square meters (m2) with a door to the street, gyms, museums, monuments, palaces, art galleries and the like.  - There is a ban on fairs and non-food markets, as well as low-risk sports.    What is allowed?  - Trade at the door for takeaway;  - Hairdressing salons, manicures and similar, with prior appointment;  - Retail establishments for books and musical supports;  - Parks, gardens, green spaces and leisure spaces;  - Libraries and archives.    Second phase of the plan    The second phase of easing of lockdown applies to the municipalities of Aljezur, Resende and Carregal do Sal.    What is allowed?  - Operation of stores up to 200 m2 with a door to the street;  - Fairs and non-food markets (by municipal decision);  - Operation of terraces, with a maximum limitation of four people per table, until 10:30 pm on weekdays and until 1:00 pm on weekends;  - Practice of sports modalities considered to be of low risk;  - Outdoor physical activity for up to four people;  - Operation of gyms without group classes;  - Functioning of social facilities in the area of ??disability.    Third phase of the plan  Miranda do Douro, Paredes and Valongo are the municipalities that remain in the third phase of the easing of lockdown.    What is allowed?    - Opening of all stores and shopping centres;  - Opening of restaurants, cafes and pasty shops (with a maximum of four people per table inside or 6 per table on terraces), until 22:30 on weekdays or 13:00 on weekends and holidays;  - Cinemas, theatres, auditoriums;  - Citizen stores with face-to-face service by appointment.  - Medium risk sports modalities;    Fourth phase of the plan    The fourth and final phase of the easing of lockdown will be applied to most of mainland Portugal, precisely 270 of the 278 municipalities.    What is allowed?    - Restaurants, cafes and pastries can operate, either during the week or on weekends, until 10:30 pm, with the limitation limited to a maximum of six people per table inside and 10 people per table on the terraces;  - Commerce in general can be open until 21:00 on weekdays and until 19:00 on weekends and holidays;  - Cultural shows start at 10:30 pm as the cut-off time;  - Practice of all sports is now allowed, as well as and for all outdoor physical activity;  - Gyms can work with group classes, observing the rules of safety and hygiene;    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173312/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-04-30/portugal-moving-into-final-phase-of-lockdown/59652    In the entire mainland, bars and clubs remain close and there is no expected date for the reopening.    Source:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669    Remote working is still mandatory, when possible, until May 16.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130182809/https://www.timeout.pt/lisboa/pt/coisas-para-fazer/o-estado-de-calamidade-foi-decretado-quais-sao-as-regras    Note: Since bars and clubs remain close, in mainland Portugal, the code remains unchanged.

The final phase of easing of lockdown for the majority of Portugal will start on Saturday, May 1, with much of the country returning to relative normality.   The advance in the easing of lockdown “applies to most of the continent's territory, it applies to 270 of the 278 counties on mainland Portugal", said António Costa.     Restrictions in place for each of the phases:    - First phase of the plan  The restrictions and measures foreseen in the first phase of the easing of lockdown plan will again be applied, starting on Saturday, in Portimão and in the parishes of São Teotónio and Almograve, in the municipality of Odemira.  Outdoor and indoor events are prohibited. There is also a ban on fairs and non-food markets.     - Second phase of the plan  The second phase of easing of lockdown applies to the municipalities of Aljezur, Resende and Carregal do Sal.  The decision to allow or not fairs and non-food markets depends on each municipality. Outdoor and indoor events are not allowed.  Operation of terraces, with a maximum limitation of four people per table, is only allowed until 10:30 pm on weekdays and until 1:00 pm on weekends and outdoor physical activity cannot exceed four participants.    - Third phase of the plan  Miranda do Douro, Paredes and Valongo are the municipalities that remain in the third phase of the easing of lockdown.  Outdoor events with reduced capacity (five people per 100 m²) are now allowed.   Restaurants, cafes and pasty shops can allow a maximum of four people per table inside or 6 per table on terraces and outdoor physical activity is allowed for groups of up to 4 people.    - Fourth phase of the plan  The fourth and final phase of the easing of lockdown will be applied to most of mainland Portugal, precisely 270 of the 278 municipalities.  No measures were announced with regards to public events (rules are the same as in the third phase) - Outdoor events with reduced capacity (five people per 100 m². In restaurants, cafes and pastries groups are limited to a maximum of six people per table inside and 10 people per table on the terraces.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173312/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-04-30/portugal-moving-into-final-phase-of-lockdown/59652    In addition to the restrictions presented above, in the entire continental territory:    - Football matches will not allow public.   - Festivals are still prohibited. However, the health authorities have started to promote pilot-events to test and understand if large public events will be allowed in the coming months.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669    On Thursday, Portugal's Prime Minister - António Costa -  announced that most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from Saturday, May 1. The  Prime Minister also announced that the parishes of São Teotónio and Longueira-Almograve would stay in a sanitary fence, due to the high incidence of cases of covid-19, especially among workers in the agricultural sector.     The sanitary fence in two parishes in the municipality of Odemira, district of Beja started at 08:00 this Friday, April 30. Circulation in the public road is not allowed, except in the situations provided for in the diploma published in the Diário da República. These exceptions include: sale and acquisition of essential goods and services in establishments that are open in these parishes; travel to and from work; for health-related reasons; support provision to the elderly, children, dependents and vulnerable individuals.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210501180700/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-04-30-Cerca-sanitaria-nas-freguesias-de-Odemira-tem-seis-passagens-f5733df2    NOTE: Considered to be a general restriction since larger events such football matches and festivals are not allowed in the entire mainland.

The final phase of easing of lockdown for the majority of Portugal will start on Saturday, May 1, with much of the country returning to relative normality.   The advance in the easing of lockdown “applies to most of the continent's territory, it applies to 270 of the 278 counties on mainland Portugal", said António Costa.     Restrictions in place for each of the phases:    - First phase of the plan (see below for additional information)  The restrictions and measures foreseen in the first phase of the easing of lockdown plan will again be applied, starting on Saturday, in Portimão and in the parishes of São Teotónio and Almograve, in the municipality of Odemira.  The setback implies the closure of terraces, shops up to 200 square meters (m2) with a door to the street, gyms, museums, monuments, palaces, art galleries and similar establishments.    - Second phase of the plan  The second phase of easing of lockdown applies to the municipalities of Aljezur, Resende and Carregal do Sal.  Operation of terraces, with a maximum limitation of four people per table, until 10:30 pm on weekdays and until 1:00 pm on weekends;  Outdoor physical activity for up to four people  Operation of gyms without group classes;    - Third phase of the plan  Miranda do Douro, Paredes and Valongo are the municipalities that remain in the third phase of the easing of lockdown.  Outdoor events with reduced capacity (five people per 100 m²) are now allowed.   Restaurants, cafes and pastries can operate with the occupation limited to four people per table inside or 6 per table on terraces).  Outdoor physical activity for up to 6 people.  Weddings and baptisms with a 25% capacity.    - Fourth phase of the plan  The fourth and final phase of the easing of lockdown will be applied to most of mainland Portugal, precisely 270 of the 278 municipalities.  Restaurants, cafes and pastries can operate with the occupation limited to a maximum of six people per table inside and 10 people per table on the terraces;    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173312/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-04-30/portugal-moving-into-final-phase-of-lockdown/59652    On Thursday, Portugal's Prime Minister - António Costa -  announced that most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from Saturday, May 1. The  Prime Minister also announced that the parishes of São Teotónio and Longueira-Almograve would stay in a sanitary fence, due to the high incidence of cases of covid-19, especially among workers in the agricultural sector.     The sanitary fence in two parishes in the municipality of Odemira, district of Beja started at 08:00 this Friday, April 30. Circulation in the public road is not allowed, except in the situations provided for in the diploma published in the Diário da República. These exceptions include: sale and acquisition of essential goods and services in establishments that are open in these parishes; travel to and from work; for health-related reasons; support provision to the elderly, children, dependents and vulnerable individuals.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210501180700/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-04-30-Cerca-sanitaria-nas-freguesias-de-Odemira-tem-seis-passagens-f5733df2

"Transports  The use of face masks is mandatory.  Public transports are limited to 2/3 of the capacity.  In taxis / TVDE, the front seats must be used only by the driver, and passenger occupancy cannot exceed 2/3 of the remaining space."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501190749/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

"Most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from May 1 and the land border with Spain will reopen for normal travel after a three-month hiatus."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/    "Citizens coming from Brazil, Cyprus, Croatia, France, India, Lithuania, Netherlands, South Africa and Sweden entering Portugal by land must comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a place indicated by the health authorities."    (...)Flights to and from Portugal are allowed for:  - Flights to and from the countries of the European Union or from Schengen Associated countries  - (...) Flights to and from other countries (which are not members of the European Union or which are not countries associated with the Schengen Area) for "essential travel" only;  - Flights intended to allow the return to Portugal of nationals or foreign citizens holding a residence permit in Portugal and flights intended to allow the return to their countries of foreign citizens who are in Portugal, provided that they are promoted by the competent authorities of those countries.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501190749/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

Most of Portugal's territory will proceed to the final phase of a gradual easing of COVID-19 restrictions from Saturday, May 1.   No changes regarding facial covering were announced. According to the Prime Minister, these will likely continue mandatory until the end of the summer, which is when herd immunity is expected to be achieved.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501172337/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-reaches-final-phase-lockdown-easing-land-border-with-spain-reopens-2021-04-29/ http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669

The government announced that the restrictions in the parishes of São Teotónio and Longueira-Almograve, in Odemira, will continue at least until next Thursday (day of the weekly evaluation).  In these two parishes terraces, larger stores, gymnasiums, museums, monuments and similar establishments, and the prohibition of fairs and non-food markets, as well as low-risk sports, remains in place. Establishments that allowed to remain open include beauty salons, manicures and with appointment, book and music stores, libraries, parks, gardens, green spaces and leisure spaces.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507233028/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/governo-decide-manter-cerca-sanitaria-em-duas-freguesias-de-odemira--13693276.html  Note: In the entire mainland, bars and clubs remain close and there is no expected date for the reopening hence the 2G code (http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669).

"The Champions League final will now be staged in Porto in Portugal after the UK government and UEFA could not reach agreement over quarantine exemptions  (...) The all-English final between Manchester City and Chelsea was originally scheduled for the Ataturk Stadium in Istanbul on May 29, but the switch will be confirmed by UEFA on Thursday.  (...) the 50,000-capacity Estadio do Dragao in Porto has now been lined up as the venue for the final after UEFA struck a deal with the Portuguese authorities over the attendance at the match. Chelsea and Manchester City will each receive a ticket allocation of between 4,500 and 6,000.  But health experts and MPs have criticised the decision for putting supporters at unnecessary risk in the middle of a pandemic, insisting UEFA should have foregone VIPs this year and made it a 'fans' final' in London."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514223553/https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/sportsnews/article-9565593/Champions-League-final-goes-Portugal-ministers-refused-waive-covid-quarantine-VIPs.html

This does not require any agreement between the employer and employees.To reinforce this rule, "all workers who have to travel for work in person [either on weekdays or at the weekend] need a credential provided by the employer".  In addition, there is no expected date for the reopening of bars and clubs. The Assistant Secretary of State for Health, António Lacerda Sales, announced on May 14, that masks will continue to be mandatory for fully vaccinated people. The decision to maintain the rules unchanged was justified by the lack of evidence regarding the possibility of vaccinated people transmitting the virus to those who are not yet vaccinated.    Source: https://archive.vn/5wgCG

""“In view of the good pace at which vaccination against Covid-19 has been taking place, it is reported that the possibility of self-scheduling is now available for ages 55 and over," says the 'task force' in a statement sent to newsrooms.  The measure to extend the age comes just four days after having opened on Sunday the appointment for over 60 years, a development that reflects the period of intensification of vaccination."  According to the 'task force' schedule, vaccinations for this new age group should only start from next 24 May.  In a table presented on 27 April, at the last Infarmed meeting, the coordinator of the national vaccination plan against Covid-19, Gouveia e Melo, said that the goal for people between 60 and 69 years of age is that everyone has a dose of the vaccine by 23 May. Already for the group between 50 and 59 years, which includes part of the population now covered with the new extension of self-scheduling, the appointed date is 13 June."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514230829/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-05-14/self-scheduling-for-vaccine-now-available-to-people-over-55/59899
Policy remains unchanged.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210522162720/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

Portugal is currently under a state of calamity. Public gatherings (outside) are limited to 10 people, except if individuals belong to the same household, in all municipalities.    In the municipalities (274) who are currently in the 4th phase of the deconfinement plan (see C2 for additional information and the list) certain events, if these follow the guidelines of the Directorate-General for Health, are allowed:    - religious ceremonies, including community celebrations  - family events, including weddings, baptisms up to 50% of the venue capacity  - corporate events held in venues suitable for this purpose, namely conference rooms, tourist establishments, venues suitable for holding trade fairs and outdoor spaces, with reduced capacity  - other indoor or outdoor events, with reduced capacity.    Funerals are allowed but measures that prevent large agglomerations of people and guarantee social distancing guidelines, namely the establishment of a maximum attendance limit, determined by local authorities, must be implemented.    In restaurants gatherings are limited to 6 people indoor 10 people on open terraces.    Source:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210522212150/https://tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade/20-05-2021/covid-19-resende-avanca-no-desconfinamento-montalegre-e-odemira-recuam    In the municipalities currently in the 3rd phase (4) the following rules apply:  - Restaurants, cafes, and bakeries can open but groups are limited to 4 and 6 people indoor and on restaurant terraces;   - Physical activity and outdoor training up to 6 people;  - Outdoor events allowed with reduced attendance.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210522161631/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Nautical events and exhibitions, aeronautical tests and exhibitions, parades, popular celebrations, folkloric manifestations or similar ones are still prohibited.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210522162828/https://www.sns24.gov.pt/tema/doencas-infecciosas/covid-19/situacao-de-calamidade/    In addition to the restrictions presented above, in the entire continental territory:    - Football matches will not allow public.   - Festivals are still prohibited. However, the health authorities have started to promote pilot-events to test and understand if large public events will be allowed in the coming months.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173124/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/30/sociedade/noticia/desconfinamento-nao-normalidade-saiba-nao-1960669    Note: Code remains unchanged since the majority large public events such as festivals, football matches, manifestations and other outdoor events are still not allowed and public gatherings (outside) are limited to 10 people

Previous measures are still in place.    In November 2020, the Government approved the ban on the suspension of essential services such water, electricity or gas during the first half of 2021, for those who are unemployed, have had a reduction in household income equal to or greater than 20%, or have been infected by Covid-19.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210323145814/https://www.dinheirovivo.pt/geral/covid-19-pagamento-faseado-de-energia-limitado-a-faturas-ate-30-de-junho-13409907.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210227072414/https://www.cgd.pt/Site/Saldo-Positivo/protecao/Pages/apoios-sociais-2021.aspx    "The Portuguese government has approved a moratorium on bank loan repayments for households and companies affected by the coronavirus outbreak which has been extended until end-September 2021. The date by which households and companies can avail themselves of the moratoria was extended to end-March 2021."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213155040/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#P    "Under the extraordinary tenant protection regime during the pandemic evictions, complaints and opposition to the renewal of housing and commercial lease agreements will continue to be suspended until June 30, 2021. The extraordinary and transitional regime for the protection of tenants, which provides for the suspension of contract terminations by landlords and the end of the lease agreements (...) on December 22, 2020, the Government's bill was approved, which extends its effects until June 2021, due to the current situation in the country. In all cases, however, the granting of this extension of the regime depends on the payment of the rent due in the respective month. This, unless the tenants are covered by the rent deferral regime (...) this provision is valid for rents due in the months of October to December 2020, as well as in the months from January to June 2021. (...) In accordance with Law no. 75-A / 2020 , which changes the exceptional regime for situations of delay in the payment of rent, provision is made for flexibility in the payment of rents (due in the months of October to December 2020 and January to June 2021) by tenants who have proven to have a drop in income as a direct consequence of the pandemic. Thus, the rent moratorium depends on financial difficulties when the following conditions are met:  - A reduction of more than 20% in the tenants household income compared to the income of the previous month or the same period of the previous year;  - An effort rate made by the household greater than 30% (given the serious consequences of the pandemic, the Executive has reduced the effort rate from 35% to 30% by proceeding with the new amendment of Law 4/2020 in December 2020)."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210227074439/https://www.cgd.pt/Site/Saldo-Positivo/protecao/Pages/protecao-contra-acao-despejo.aspx
Ongoing public health campaign.    Sources: https://archive.vn/tsZz0  http://web.archive.org/web/20210522161332/https://covid19.min-saude.pt/

"Portugal is to resume admitting tourists from most European countries on Monday, the interior ministry said, following months of restrictions to prevent the spread of Covid-19.  Travellers from European Union countries with coronavirus rates below 500 cases per 100,000 residents over a 14-day period can make "all types of visits to Portugal, including even non-essential visits," the ministry said in a statement.  Tourists from Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland and Switzerland are also allowed to start flying to Portugal.  Visitors will have to show proof of a negative test taken up to 72 hours before a flight and airlines will be fined between €500 and €2,000 for each passenger who boards without presenting proof of a negative test.  The ministry said restrictions, limited to essential trips, would be maintained for five EU countries - Cyprus, Croatia, Lithuania, the Netherlands and Sweden - plus Brazil, India and South Africa.  Yesterday, Portugal said it will allow holidaymakers from Britain to enter the country from Monday (...) European Union rules prohibit non-essential travel from outside the bloc, making Portugal's decision to allow in UK tourists an exception."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210519023205/https://www.rte.ie/news/coronavirus/2021/0515/1221758-coronavirus-europe/

The Minister of State and the Presidency announced this Thursday that the municipality of Resende will move forward in the process of deconfinement. In the opposite direction, in Montalegre and Odemira the measures enacted on April 19 will apply. In addition, Arganil and Lamego are again subject to the same restrictions, since the indicators on the incidence of covid-19 per 100 thousand inhabitants do not show significant improvements. In these municipalities, all shops and shopping centers, restaurants, cafes and pastry shops are open (with a maximum of four people per table inside or six by table on terraces) until 22:30 on weekdays or 13:00 on weekends and holidays. Cinemas, theaters, auditoriums, concert halls, Lojas do Cidadão with in-person service are also open.     With the exception of the four counties that are now in the third phase of deconfinement, the remaining 274 municipalities, including those on alert, remain in the fourth phase of the deconfinment plan. In this phase, restaurants and shows are allowed to operate/take place until 10:30 pm, shops in general until 9:00 pm on weekdays and until 7:00 pm on weekends and holidays. Restaurants, cafes and pastry shops can operate but tables are allowed to have a maximum of six people per table inside and ten people per table on the terraces. All sports can be practiced, as well as all physical activity outdoors. The capacity for weddings and baptisms is limited to 50% of the venue capacity. Amusement parks, children's playgrounds, other than public ones, and water parks may operate in these municipalities.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210522212150/https://tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade/20-05-2021/covid-19-resende-avanca-no-desconfinamento-montalegre-e-odemira-recuam    Note: Bars, nightclubs, casinos and similar establishments remain closed in the entire mainland - hence the 2G code (http://web.archive.org/web/20210522162828/https://www.sns24.gov.pt/tema/doencas-infecciosas/covid-19/situacao-de-calamidade/).

"The task force for vaccination against covid-19 in Portugal will implement a system that involves the initiation of simultaneous vaccination for various age groups with a one week interval between them, between the end of May and the beginning of June.  The over-50s will start to be vaccinated first; a week later jabs will start to be given to the over-40s, and one week later the over-30s.    The objective, according to reports, is to take advantage of Johnson & Johnson's vaccines for the over-50s, and use Pfizer and Moderna for other age groups."    Source: https://archive.vn/Sy7Cn

The Plan to Reactivate Tourism "Building the Future", presented this Friday, May 21, 2021 by the Minister of Economy, foresees an investment of 6112 million euros in the tourism sector in the coming years.    "Our goal is to reach 2027 at the level we projected in 2017. In 2017 we had projected a pace of growth in tourism revenue that would reach 27 billion euros in 2027. The crisis could leave us below this objective. Our plan aims to bring us at that level and, if possible, surpass it ", affirmed the Minister of State, Economy and Digital Transition, Pedro Siza Vieira, in the session of presentation of the plan.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210523131253/https://www.dn.pt/dinheiro/governo-anuncia-plano-de-6112-milhoes-de-euros-para-o-turismo-13750400.html    Exchange rate May 21: 1 EUR = 1.217708 USD (Source: https://archive.vn/haCNR)    Note: Recorded on the day the plan was announced since the exact date in which the spending will begin was not found.

May 26 - The minister of Labour, Solidarity and Social Security, Ana Mendes Godinho, requested nursing homes to allow residents to leave the facilities and have visitors. In this audience at the Parliamentary Committee, the Minister added that the Social Security Institute had made this request twice to these institutions and reminded that the rights of those living in these facilities should be respected and safeguarded. She also added that recalled that at this stage the majority of residents and workers working in these institutions have been vaccinated.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210605011402/https://rr.sapo.pt/2021/05/26/pais/governo-pede-que-seja-respeitado-direito-dos-utentes-dos-lares-para-sair-e-ter-visitas/noticia/240180/    Note: Code remains unchanged easing of limitations for e.g. with regards to visitors were not found.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514220806/https://www.timeout.pt/lisboa/pt/coisas-para-fazer/o-estado-de-calamidade-foi-decretado-quais-sao-as-regras

Previous policies are still in place (see note May 20).  With regards to teleworking "The Council of Ministers approved today [this Thursday] a resolution extending the situation of calamity in the entire continental national territory until 23:59 on June 13 , 2021" (...)  the adoption of teleworking remains mandatory in all municipalities in the country (...) until June 13."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210528120627/https://eco.sapo.pt/2021/05/27/teletrabalho-mantem-se-obrigatorio-ate-13-de-junho/

Vice Admiral Henrique Gouveia e Melo (leader of the vaccination task force) explained that vaccination will be accelerated in the entire country due to the fact that a large number of vaccines have arrived. Some regions, including Lisbon and Vale do Tejo, Norte and Algarve are behind due to the different age structure. He also added that until the end of the week vaccination for those over 60 will be completed and today (Thursday) those over 50 will be able to schedule their vaccination online.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210526220528/https://www.tsf.pt/portugal/sociedade/todo-o-pais-vai-ser-acelerado-em-termos-de-vacinacao-13773347.html

The Government has decided to prolong the current ‘State of Calamity’ decreed for the whole of mainland Portugal in the scope of the fight against the Covid-19 pandemic until June 13.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210605013423/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-05-28/government-extends-state-of-calamity-until-june-13/60130    Under the "State of Calamity" no valid reason is necessary to circulate or visit public places, however, the civic duty to stay at home (individual decision that is recommended).    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210605013324/https://www.deco.proteste.pt/familia-consumo/orcamento-familiar/noticias/situacao-calamidade-regras-desconfinamento

Resolution of the Council of Ministers No. 64-A/2021 - May 28, 2021    "The following individuals may be subject to SARS-CoV-2 diagnostic tests:    (...) visitors to residential structures for the elderly, integrated continuous care units of the Network National Integrated Continuing Care and other structures and responses dedicated to the elderly (...)     Measures in the context of residential structures    1 - The protection of residents in residential structures for the elderly, integrated continuing care units of the National Integrated Continuing Care Network and other residential structures and responses (...) given their special vulnerability, should involve:    a) Self-surveillance of disease symptoms by professionals working in these units, as well as surveillance of residents' symptoms and regular screening in order to identify suspected cases early;    b) Mandatory use of surgical masks by all professionals working in these structures;    c) Testing of all residents if a positive case is detected in any contact;    d) Immediate placement of municipal equipment or other for any need for accommodation of people in prophylactic isolation or in a situation of confirmed infection of the COVID-19 disease that, in view of the clinical evaluation, does not determine the need for hospitalization;    e) Permission (...) to carry out visits to users, in compliance with the rules defined by the DGS, and assessment of the need to suspend them for a limited time and according to the specific epidemiological situation, in conjunction with the local health authority;    f) Clinical follow-up of COVID-19 patients whose clinical situation does not require hospitalization by health professionals from the health center groups in the respective intervention area, in conjunction with the hospital in the reference area;    g) Operationalization of rapid intervention teams, consisting of direct action assistants, general service assistants, nurses, psychologists and doctors with the capacity for immediate action in the containment and stabilization of outbreaks of the COVID-19 disease"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210612012800/https://dre.pt/home/-/dre/164321573/details/maximized
Policy remains unchanged.    Source: https://archive.vn/ti7GG

"The resumption of air routes with the countries of the European Union, as well as in the Schengen Area, is dependent on border restrictions and on the evolution of the epidemiological situation worldwide.     (...) Flights to and from Portugal are allowed for:  Non-essential travels from the countries of the European Union, from Schengen Associated countries (Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland) and from the UK (...) Passengers must present proof of a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before boarding time.    Countries with an incidence rate equal to or greater than 500 cases per 100,000 inhabitants - Brazil, India and South Africa:  - Only “essential travel” is allowed  - Must present proof of a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before boarding time  - It is compulsory to comply with a prophylactic isolation period of 14 days, at home or in a place indicated by the health authorities, after entering mainland Portugal  The list of countries is determined by govenmental document, reviewed every 15 days and whenever necessary according to the pandemic evolution.    Flights from Australia, China, Israel, South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand, and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau (subject to confirmation of reciprocity).    Flights to and from other countries (which are not members of the European Union or which are not countries associated with the Schengen Area) for "essential travel" only".    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210605001751/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal
Ongoing public health campaign.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210601154144/https://www.sns24.gov.pt/

Restrictions implemented on 5 April, but maintained from May 30th to June 13th in the municipality of Arganil  - Opening of museums, monuments, palaces, art galleries and similar;  - Opening of shops up to 200 m2 with a door to the street;  - Non-food fairs and markets allowed upon municipal decision;  - Opening of terraces (groups of maximum 4 people allowed);  - Opening of swimming pools;  - Opening of golf courses.    Restrictions implemented on 19 April, but maintained from May 30th to June 13th in the municipalities of Montalegre and Odemira  - Opening of cinemas, theatres, auditoriums, concert halls;  - Opening of all shops and shopping centres until 9 pm on working days and until 1 pm on weekends and public holidays;  - Opening of restaurants, cafes, and bakeries until 10:30 pm on working days and until 1 pm on weekends and public holidays. Groups of 4 people are allowed inside or 6 people on terraces;    Measures implemented on May 1 - Implemented in the remaining municipalities  - Opening of restaurants, cafés, and pastry shops until 10.30 p.m. Groups of 6 people are allowed inside or 10 people on terraces;    From May 13:  - Fun fairs;  - Private amusement parks;  - Water parks."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210605001751/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Note: Bars, nightclubs, casinos and similar establishments remain closed in the entire mainland - hence the 2G code. There is no expected start date for the reopening. The coordinator of the COVID-19 vaccination task force, Vice Admiral Gouveia e Melo, announced that people between 20 and 30 years old will likely start being vaccinated in early August. In addition, starting on Sunday, June 6th, people over 40 years old will be called through local appointments and one week later these will be made available online. He also announced that those who had COVID-19 six months ago have started being vaccinated.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210605012434/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2021-06-01-Covid-19.-Pessoas-entre-os-20-e-os-30-anos-comecam-a-ser-vacinadas-em-agosto-avanca-Gouveia-e-Melo-a94b6bd7

"Traditional festivals/festivities will continue to be suspended on the Portuguese mainland during the months of July and August, Prime Minister António Costa announced today, justifying the measure with the high concentration of people involved in these events."  (...) When asked about the creation of entertainment areas in Porto during São João, António Costa said that the Government spoke with the municipality and stressed that traditional festivities are not planned, "but the holding of three events, in three open-air spaces, with limited capacity and agreed between the Porto City Council and the health authorities", whereby "the rules of the events" currently applied will be followed.  "As for situations of non-compliance with removal regulations, it is naturally up to the security forces to ensure compliance with the regulations," he added.  Source: https://archive.vn/RvAYm

Policy remains unchanged.  In addition, the Prime-Minister, António Costa announced in a press conference that it is premature to make any changes to current policy since the transmission rate is still high. He added that evidence is still limited on whether vaccinated individuals are able to spread the virus or not.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210602160213/https://www.jn.pt/nacional/bares-lojas-restaurantes-e-desporto-o-que-muda-e-o-que-fica-na-mesma-13797405.html

"Scrambling to save its tourism sector, Portugal said on Wednesday it would allow U.S. visitors into the country but added Nepal to a list of "red" nations amid worries about new coronavirus variants.  Portugal is now open to tourists from EU countries and Britain but they must show a negative COVID-19 test result on arrival. Since June 15, rules applied to UK visitors also apply to those coming from the United States, the government said.  Travellers from Japan, Australia, South Korea, China, Israel, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore and Thailand will also be able to travel to Portugal as long as their governments adopt equivalent reciprocal measures.  (...) Portugal is lifting travel restrictions on some countries but imposing new rules on others. A ban on non-essential travel applies to all non-EU and non-Schengen zone countries not listed by the government as an exception.  Travellers from Nepal, where daily cases have been dropping but where the new variant of COVID-19 initially discovered in neighbouring India has been detected, must quarantine for 14 days upon arrival."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210618235859/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-allows-us-tourists-imposes-travel-restrictions-nepal-2021-06-16/

"The Government announced this Wednesday that COVID-19 testing will be mandatory to have access to sports, cultural and family events, including weddings and baptisms.  It will also be necessary to carry out tests in companies with more than 150 workers. (...) The minister explained that these companies, as determined by the health authority, are, similarly to what happens at this time in agriculture and civil construction, to test their staff.  Mariana Vieira da Silva explained that the cost of the tests will be borne by the companies and that this testing requirement "depends on the guidelines provided by the health authority that will determine the locations in which, given the level of incidence, evolution or growth, this control must done".   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210611231830/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/quatro-concelhos-nao-avancam-e-ha-dez-em-alerta-13820087.html
Policy remains unchanged.    Source: https://archive.ph/Zrzii

"The self-scheduling of the vaccine against Covid-19 will be available from the next few hours this Monday for people aged 40 or over (...) Since last Monday, those aged 43 or over can schedule an appointment for the vaccine, which will now be extended.   According to Público , those over 30 should also be able to schedule the vaccine from next Sunday, June 20 (...) people over 30 and 40 years old will be vaccinated at the same time. The goal is to avoid wasting the Janssen vaccine, which, last Tuesday, was recommended by the General Directorate of Health to all men aged 18 years and over.  Until this Monday, in mainland Portugal, more than six million and five hundred thousand doses of vaccines against Covid-19 had been administered — more than four million first doses and more than two million second doses."  Source: https://observador.pt/2021/06/14/pessoas-com-40-ou-mais-anos-podem-agendar-vacinacao-a-partir-desta-segunda-feira/

"The lack of information related to the number of users of the National Health Service (SNS) unabled the Directorate General of Health to process the data collected in the four test events held in April and May, with the aim of allowing an increase in the capacity of the rooms and the organization of outdoor events (...) a source from the Directorate General of Health explained that "to complete the monitoring it is necessary to match the identification information that was used to access the events with the NHS user number, which makes the process more time-consuming", adding, that "the results will be released as soon as the process is completed".  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210619011414/https://www.cmjornal.pt/cultura/detalhe/20210616-0836-falta-de-dados-atrasa-resultados-de-eventos

"The Directorate-General of Health updated today, June 17, the Norm referring to the National Testing Strategy for SARS-CoV-2, reinforcing the performance of laboratory tests as a measure to control community transmission.  There is now an obligation to carry out laboratory tests at family events, including weddings and baptisms, as well as any other similar celebrations, with gathering of people outside the household, professionals and participants whenever the number of participants exceeds 10.  In cultural, sporting or corporate events, testing must be carried out whenever the number of participants/spectators exceeds 1,000, in an open environment, or more than 500, in a closed environment."  Source: https://archive.vn/o3AJH

June 17 - "The Directorate-General of Health updated today, June 17, the Norm referring to the National Testing Strategy for SARS-CoV-2, reinforcing the performance of laboratory tests as a measure to control community transmission. There is now an obligation to carry out laboratory tests at family events, including weddings and baptisms, as well as any other similar celebrations, with gathering of people outside the household, professionals and participants whenever the number of participants exceeds 10." "The Directorate-General of Health updated today, June 17, the Norm referring to the National Testing Strategy for SARS-CoV-2, reinforcing the performance of laboratory tests as a measure to control community transmission.  There is now an obligation to carry out laboratory tests at family events, including weddings and baptisms, as well as any other similar celebrations, with gathering of people outside the household, professionals and participants whenever the number of participants exceeds 10.  In cultural, sporting or corporate events, testing must be carried out whenever the number of participants/spectators exceeds 1,000, in an open environment, or more than 500, in a closed environment. The same recommendation must be followed in public services and in workplaces with 150 or more workers (...)"  Source: https://archive.vn/o3AJH

"From June 10  - Restaurants, cafés, and pastry shops must close at 1 am, with admission until midnight.  - Cultural facilities must close at 1 am, with admission until midnight. 50% capacity limit.  - Outdoor events with marked places, distance rules and other specific rules to be defined by the General Directorate of Health.  - Amateur sports and training events, with public, will have marked places and distance rules defined by the DGS. In sports venues they can only occupy 33% of the capacity.  - Shops and shopping centres without time restrictions.  - Public transport without capacity restriction. Maximum occupancy of 2/3 when seating and standing.  - Taxis and TVDE with limited capacity for the rear seats.    Between June 28th and August 31st  - Professional sports events with public, with marked places and with distance and access rules to be defined by the DGS. In sports venues they can only have 33% of the capacity. Outside sports venues will have capacity and rules to be defined by the DGS.  - Public transport without restriction of capacity.    (...) - Rules applied to high-risk municipalities (Albufeira, Arruda dos Vinhos, Braga, Cascais, Lisbon, Loulé, Odemira, Sertã e Sintra)  Municipalities with a 14-day cumulative incidence of more than 120 cases per 100,000 inhabitants in two consecutive assessments:  Restaurants, cafés and pastry shops close at 10.30 p.m. Limitation of groups of 6 people inside and 10 people on the terraces.  Cultural shows must end by 10.30 p.m.  (...) Shops and supermarkets must close by 9pm.  Physical activity allowed outdoors and in gyms.    (...) - Rules applied to very high-risk municipalities - Sesimbra  Municipalities with a 14-day cumulative incidence of more than 240 cases per 100,000 inhabitants in two consecutive assessments.  Restaurants, cafes and bakeries must close by 10.30 p.m. during the week and by 3.30 p.m. on weekends and public holidays. Limitation of groups of 4 people inside and 6 people on the terraces.  Cultural shows must end by 10.30 p.m.  (...) Supermarkets and grocery stores can operate until 9pm during the week and until 7pm on weekends and public holidays.  Shops may operate until 9 p.m. during the week and until 3.30 p.m. on weekends and public holidays."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210619000323/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Note: Bars, nightclubs, casinos and similar establishments remain closed in the entire mainland - hence the 2G code. There is no expected start date for the reopening. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210625003829/https://www.rtp.pt/noticias/pais/mais-de-1000-inqueritos-epidemiologicos-atrasados-em-lisboa-e-vale-do-tejo_v1328975

"free testing at pharmacies in Lisbon is no longer limited to two monthly tests per resident in the city, that is now offering an unlimited number of tests, regardless of whether you are a resident of Lisbon or not, informed the Lisbon City Council. Since March 31, when the autarchy's program started, more than 60 000 free tests have been carried out for Lisbon residents.  The number of tests carried out, in pharmacies and mobile stations organized by the local authority and the Red Cross, more than doubled in the last week: from a daily average of 1,000 tests to more than 3,500 tests/day, on 17 and 18 June.  The network of mobile testing points, with 17 points, will also be reinforced as of this week (...) Starting this Monday, teams from the municipal civil protection services will be in the main commercial areas to “raise, door to door, local businesses and restaurants to the need to test their employees”.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210625212728/https://rr.sapo.pt/2021/06/23/pais/covid-19-lisboa-com-mais-um-centro-de-vacinacao-a-partir-de-quarta-feira/noticia/243498/

"The Minister of Health, Marta Temido, said this Tuesday that there is no need to limit visits to nursing homes again, noting that people who are vaccinated and then get infected with COVID-19 develop only "mild illness".    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210625002638/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/ministra-da-saude-afasta-limitacao-de-visitas-a-lares--13862440.html    Visitors to care homes and long-term care facilities must:  "schedule their visits with a limited time (not to exceed 90 minutes)  respect the limit of one visitor per user  respect physical distance requirements, respiratory etiquette and hand hygiene  use a mask, preferably surgical, during the entire period of stay in the institution  not take personal objects, food or other products  do not move around the institution or use the users' sanitary facilities.  ensure that the visit takes place in its own space, spacious and with airing conditions, and visits should not be carried out in the user's living room or in the bedroom itself, except in cases where the user is bedridden  visitors who test positive for COVID-19 should inform the local health authority if they have visited the institution within 48 hours before the onset of symptoms  communication using video call or telephone should be privileged   if visitors have signs or symptoms suggestive of COVID-19 or have had contact with a suspected or confirmed case of COVID-19 in the last 14 days they should not visitors"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210626132549/https://www.sns24.gov.pt/tema/doencas-infecciosas/covid-19/desconfinamento/

The vaccination task force announced elderly and employees of homes who have been infected for more than three months will start being vaccinated against covid-19. Previously the minimum period was 6 months. A source from the structure that coordinates the vaccination logistics said that Social Security had identified around 8600 people to be vaccinated in elderly homes, among users and employees of these structures. Due to the increased risk of most of this universe, given their advanced age, the task force and the Directorate-General for Health (DGS) considered it prudent to make an exception to the provisions of standard 002/2021 and proceed with the vaccination of all employees and users who were infected more than 3 months ago (and not 6 months). The DGS standard indicates that people who have recovered from SARS-CoV-2 virus infection for at least six months can be vaccinated, but will receive only one dose of vaccine, bearing in mind that, as they have already had the disease and have immunity.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210626131950/https://www.publico.pt/2021/06/22/sociedade/noticia/task-force-antecipa-vacinacao-lares-1967530

Those aged 35 and above are now able to schedule their vaccination appointment online.  By June 20, more than 4.7 million people had already received the first dose of the COVID-19 vaccine, equivalent to 46% of the population and 2.9 million, equivalent to 29% of the Portuguese population were fully vaccinated. In one week, 381,498 additional people were fully vaccinated against covid-19.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210625004630/https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/coronavirus/detalhe/autoagendamento-da-vacina-para-maiores-de-35-anos-ja-esta-disponivel  The COVID-19 task force announced today that those aged 18 and above will start being vaccinated on July 4th.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210625005009/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-06-23-Covid-19.-Vacinacao-para-maiores-de-18-anos-comeca-a-4-de-julho-12c1990a

GENERAL RULES in the entire country:    - Restaurants, cafés, and pastry shops close at 1 am.  - Shops and shopping centres are open, without time restrictions.  - Cultural facilities close at 1 am. 50% capacity limit.  - Alcoholic beverages sale is prohibited in service areas or gas stations and, from 9 p.m., in shops including supermarkets  - Golf courses are fully operational.  - Telework is recommended but not mandatory.    2. EXCEPTIONS    a. In Alcochete, Almada, Amadora, Arruda dos Vinhos, Barreiro, Braga, Cascais, Grândola, Lagos, Loulé, Loures, Mafra, Moita, Montijo, Odemira, Odivelas, Oeiras, Palmela, Sardoal, Seixal, Setúbal, Sines, Sintra, Sobral de Monte Agraço, Vila Franca de Xira:  - Restaurants, cafés and pastry shops close at 10.30 p.m. Limitation of groups of 6 people inside and 10 people on the terraces.  - Cultural shows end by 10.30 p.m.  - Shops and supermarkets closed after 9pm.  - Telework is mandatory, whenever possible.    b. In Lisboa, Sesimbra, Albufeira:  - Restaurants, cafes and bakeries closed after 10.30 p.m. during weekdays and after 3.30 p.m. on weekends and public holidays. Limitation of groups of 4 people inside and 6 people on the terraces.  - Cultural shows not allowed after 10.30 p.m.  - Supermarkets and grocery stores open until 9pm during the weekdays and until 7pm on weekends and public holidays.  - Shops open until 9 p.m. on weekdays and until 3.30 p.m. on weekends and public holidays.  - Telework is mandatory, whenever possible.    Sources: https://archive.vn/IMf3c  http://web.archive.org/web/20210625214128/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/aumenta-para-28-o-numero-de-concelhos-com-teletrabalho-obrigatorio--13871487.html     Bars, nightclubs, casinos and similar establishments remain closed in the entire mainland - hence the 2G code. There is no expected start date for the reopening.     Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210605002631/https://www.sns24.gov.pt/tema/doencas-infecciosas/covid-19/situacao-de-calamidade/.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210602160213/https://www.jn.pt/nacional/bares-lojas-restaurantes-e-desporto-o-que-muda-e-o-que-fica-na-mesma-13797405.html

"MAINLAND Portugal    ALLOWED (Essential and non-essential travel)  Countries of the European Union, Schengen Associated countries (Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland), UK, Australia, New Zealand, China, Israel, Japan, South Korea, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand, the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau and the United States of America    RT-PCR Test (or similar NAAT test) - 72h before boarding, or  Rapid Antigen Test - 48h before boarding, or  EU Digital COVID Certificate (from 1 July)  Children under 12 do not need to present test. June 9, 2021 - The Portuguese Parliament approved the extension of diploma that makes the use of masks (those aged 10 or above) mandatory outside, in cases when social distancing is not possible, until mid-September. Individuals who have a medical justification or who belong the same household (in cases when other people are not present) are excempt. Due to increase in the number of cases in the Algarve, the Regional Health Administration of the Algarve (ARS) decided to suspend in-person classes for students in primary and middle school (both in public and private schools) in five municipalities in the region. The measure was announced on Sunday, June 27, and takes effect today, Monday, 28, with a duration of 12 days — coinciding with the end of the school year, on June 8th."
