The Portuguese Red Cross is carrying out PCR tests that provide results in 13 minutes. The new testing method was introduced this Thursday, but since June 1215 tests have already been carried out in various cities across the country.  Source: https://archive.vn/q4Pv1

Previous measures remain in place.    July 1 - Considering the current epidemiological situation, the Government extends until September 30 the conditions for payment of the Covid-19 sickness subsidy, which is paid in the amount corresponding to 100% of the net reference remuneration.    Source: https://archive.vn/GxsL8

"The Portuguese government has approved a moratorium on bank loan repayments for households and companies affected by the coronavirus outbreak which has been extended until end-September 2021. The date by which households and companies can avail themselves of the moratoria was extended to end-March 2021."    Source: https://archive.vn/Aczcv    "A decree-law was approved that safeguards that the current beneficiaries of the rent payment support scheme can access it until 1 October 2021, verifying the need to maintain a set of measures aimed, in the short term, to safeguard the right to housing.     Modifications to this exceptional and temporary regime were also introduced to ensure that the beneficiaries, between the moment of submission of the request for support and the final decision by the IHRU, are not subject to the effects of default or contractual breach.    The ban on the suspension of the supply of essential services such water, electricity, natural gas and electronic communications services was also extended."    Source: https://archive.vn/GxsL8

"The decree-law that extends the current conditions of extraordinary support for the progressive resumption of activity in companies in a situation of business crisis was approved. Thus, companies with billing breaks equal to or greater than 75% can reduce the Normal Working Period (PNT) up to 100% during the months of July and August. This PNT reduction is available to a maximum of 75% of employees working for the employer. In companies in the sectors of bars, nightclubs, recreational parks and the supply or assembly of events, the 100% reduction in the PNT can cover all workers.  The Government also approved the continuation, until August 31, of extraordinary support for the reduction of the economic activity of self-employed workers, for professionals whose activities are framed in the sectors of tourism, culture and events and shows (and whose CAE and CIRS are planned in Ordinance No. 85/2021), which were especially affected by the impact of the pandemic, until 31 August.  Access to the support provided for in articles 26 and 28-A of DL 10-A/2020, in its current wording, is also guaranteed for independent workers and members of statutory bodies that fall into activities that have been suspended or terminated by legislative or administrative determination of a governmental source."  Source: https://archive.vn/GxsL8

Starting on Thursday, July 1st, the government will start providing a 100% refund for rapid antigen tests (for professional use). This measure will be in place until July 31st and might be extended. However, there are a few exceptions: it is limited to 4 tests per month/per person (the maximum amount has been fixated at 10€) and those who have completed their vaccinatation in the past 14 days, those who have had COVID-19 in the past 180 days (and have a certificate) are excluded. Only patients of the Sistema Nacional de Saúde (National Health System) are eligible.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210701214059/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/comparticipacao-de-testes-rapidos-de-antigenio-entra-em-vigor-esta-quinta-feira-13890972.html

EXCEPTIONS    In Alcochete, Alenquer, Arruda dos Vinhos, Avis, Braga, Castelo de Vide, Faro, Grândola, Lagoa, Lagos, Montijo, Odemira, Palmela, Paredes de Coura, Portimão, Porto, Rio Maior, Santarém, São Brás de Alportel, Sardoal, Setúbal, Silves, Sines, Sousel, Torres Vedras e Vila Franca de Xira:  - Telework is mandatory, whenever functions allowed.  - Restaurants, cafés and pastry shops close at 10.30 p.m. Limitation of groups of 6 people inside and 10 people on the terraces.  - Cultural shows end by 10.30 p.m.  - Shops and supermarkets closed after 9pm.  - Practice of all sports allowed, without public.  - Physical activity allowed outdoors and in gyms.  - Amusement parks and similar establishments must close.   - Water and amusement parks, casinos and similar establishments must close.     In Albufeira, Almada, Amadora, Barreiro, Cascais, Constância, Lisbon, Loulé, Loures, Mafra, Mira, Moita, Odivelas, Oeiras, Olhão, Seixal, Sesimbra, Sintra e Sobral de Monte Agraço:  - Telework is mandatory, whenever functions allowed  - Restaurants, cafes and bakeries closed after 10.30 p.m. during weekdays and after 3.30 p.m. on weekends and public holidays. Limitation of groups of 4 people inside and 6 people on the terraces.  - Cultural shows not allowed after 10.30 p.m.  - Supermarkets and grocery stores open until 9pm during the weekdays and until 7pm on weekends and public holidays.  - Shops open until 9 p.m. on weekdays and until 3.30 p.m. on weekends and public holidays.  - Sporting activities of medium risk allowed but without public.  - Water and amusement parks, casinos and similar establishments should close/remain closed. The diploma that extends some of the most favorable modalities of the so-called "support for recovery" will enter in force today. The diploma also extends subsidies in the case of covid-19 and support for the reduction of activity to some self-employed workers, managers and entrepreneurs.  Companies with a reduction of revenues of 75% or more will continue to be able to reduce the normal working hours of up to 100% of workers, depending on the sector.  In situations of illness COVID-19, the attribution of a sickness allowance that is not subject to a waiting period is extended until the end of September. The allowance corresponds to "100% of the net reference pay and has a maximum limit of 28 days".  The Government extended the subsidy for reduced activity only to independent workers, managers and entrepreneurs from sectors especially affected by the pandemic, namely in the tourism of tourism, culture, events and shows, until August 31st. The amount ranges between 219 euros and 665 euros. In principle, they are eligible when there is a 40% break in revenues. As for the other sectors of activity, support is only granted when the activities have been "suspended or closed". Closing is only considered when it is established "by legislative determination of a government source", which at this moment happens essentially with bars and clubs.   Source: https://archive.vn/dkXNJ

The Minister of Health, Marta Temido, announced that the daily average of SARS-CoV-2 virus diagnostic tests reached the highest number since the beginning of the pandemic in the first week of July.  "The testing campaign has been strengthened. In these few days of July, the daily average of tests is the highest since the beginning of the pandemic, also higher January," (...) In the first month of 2021, the average number of tests performed per day was around 52,000, according to data released on January 29 by the National Institute of Health Dr. Ricardo Jorge (INSA)."  Source: https://archive.vn/3ZFDs

The Minister of Health, Marta Temido, announced in the Health Comission that "According with the data available, the isolation of cases and isolation of contactos - that are direct indicators of the tracing and identification of the epidemiological "link" - are still made during the 24h window in 98 and 78% of cases." She also noted that public health departments have been able to identify epidemiological connections in more than half of the reported cases.   Source: https://archive.vn/3ZFDs

Portuguese academic institutions are currently closed for the summer (From July 8th onwards).   Up until the academic break, there was a targeted closure in Algavre as seen here: [ http://web.archive.org/web/20210701210552/https://magg.sapo.pt/atualidade/atualidade-nacional/artigos/alunos-ciclo-algarve-terminar-ano-letivo-aulas-distancia ]  It was held that this targeted closure would lapse on July 8th. As such, coding level 1 has been reinstated, and will stay in place until schools reopen as per the interpretation guide.   Whilst there are not yet restrictions in place for the reopening of academic institutions in mid-september, there is currently a great deal of focus on vaccinating school-aged children, with the hope that all school-aged children will be vaccinated before school resumes, as seen here: [ https://web.archive.org/web/20210825072924/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-08-20/vaccine-schedule-extended-for-12-to-17-year-olds/61877 ]

The Government announced, after the Council of Ministers meeting, on Thursday that a digital certificate or a negative test will be required to access tourist establishments across the country, regardless of the level of risk in the municipalities from Monday to Sunday at all times.   In high and very high risk councils, individuals are required to present the certificate or a negative test in restaurants for indoor dining services. This measure will be in effect on Fridays from 7pm and throughout the day on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. This time, the restaurants can be open until 22:30 on weekends and holidays and not until 15:30, as was the case until now.  These new rules will begin to be applied from 3:30 pm this Saturday (10th).  Source: https://archive.vn/hshht  Bars and clubs have been closed since March 2020 and the government recently announced that these establishments will remain closed, in the entire mainland, at least until the end of August.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210702165156/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-06-30-Lisboa-recomenda-ao-Governo-reabertura-de-discotecas-para-portadores-de-certificado-b2b6d752

The Government announced, after the Council of Ministers meeting, on Thursday that a digital certificate or a negative test will be required to access tourist establishments across the country, regardless of the level of risk in the municipalities from Monday to Sunday at all times.   In high and very high risk councils, individuals are required to present the certificate or a negative test in restaurants for indoor dining services. This measure will be in effect on Fridays from 7pm and throughout the day on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. This time, the restaurants can be open until 22:30 on weekends and holidays and not until 15:30, as was the case until now.  These new rules, however, clarified the minister, will only begin to be applied from 3:30 pm this Saturday (10th).  Four types of tests are valid:  PCR test , performed within 72 hours; Antigen test with laboratory report, performed within 48 hours; Rapid antigen test in the self-test mode , carried out within 24 hours in the presence of a health or pharmaceutical professional who then certifies the result; Antigen self-test carried out at the door of the establishment in the presence of the staff.  Source: https://archive.vn/hshht

Extraordinary Support for the Reduction of the Economic Activity for Self-Employed Workers  "From May it is intended for self-employed workers and sole proprietors (...) subject to suspension of activities or closure of facilities and establishments by legislative or administrative determination of a government source. This support also covers self-employed workers and sole proprietors (...) who exercise an activity in the tourism, culture, events or spectacle sectors (...)  The value of the average monthly annual income of the worker in the year 2019 (...) with the maximum limit of 1 IAS (438.81€), when the value of the average annual monthly income of the worker in the year 2019 is less than 1.5 IAS (658.22€). A 2/3 of the average monthly annual income of the worker (...) with the maximum limit equal to the RMMG (665€), when the value of the average annual monthly income of the worker in the year 2019 is equal to or greater than 1.5 IAS (658.22€).  The planned support has as minimum limit the value corresponding to 50% of the value of the IAS (219,41€)."  Source: https://archive.vn/LB1Nj  Note: Median salary in Portugal (2020) = 1314€ (source: https://archive.vn/Shrgm)

Visits limitations in care homes and similar establishments continue to apply in the entire country for both those who are unvaccinated and vaccinated (or who can present a proof of a negative test result). Cinemas, theaters, museums, conference and cultural centers: open to the public.  Grocery stores and supermarkets: normal hours of service resumed.  Public Services: Lojas do Cidadão open for in-person services by appointment only.  Hotels, Guesthouses, and airBnBs: mandatory submission of an EU Digital Certificate or a negative COVID test result (PCR 72 hours; antigen 48 hours; rapid test before health official 24 hours; or a rapid test immediately on arrival in front of an employee) is now required upon check-in.  Cafés and Restaurants: limited to groups of 6 inside and 10 outside, are permitted to be open until 1am during weekdays and weekends (last admissions at midnight).  Note – for indoor dining after 7pm on Friday, on weekends, and on holidays in high-risk and very high-risk municipalities (such as Lisbon) the same mandatory submission of an EU Digital Certificate or a negative COVID test result (PCR 72 hours; antigen 48 hours; rapid test before health official 24 hours; or a rapid test immediately on arrival in front of an employee) is now required for admission.  Stores and shopping centers – normal hours of business resumed.  Sports: All sports activities permitted including outdoor exercise.  Gymnasiums fully open according to DGS health and safety regulations  Cultural events: Open to the public until 1am (last admission at midnight).  Hairdressers, manicurists, and barbers open by appointment only.  Weddings and baptisms permitted at 50% capacity.  Alcoholic beverages cannot be sold in gas stations all day. Alcohol sales for takeaway or delivery are prohibited between 9PM and 6AM. Public consumption of alcoholic beverages is forbidden except inside restaurants and when order with meals.  Telework still recommended, when possible  Theatres at 50% of capacity; Outside theatres, rules as determined by health authorities. "(...) in the beginning of the 2021/2022 school year (...) teaching and non-teaching staff of all years of schooling as well as high school and middle school students (...) regardless of their vaccination status, will be tested (...) The testing process, similarly to the last school year, will take place in a phased manner, taking into account the existing testing capacity in the country, starting with teaching and non-teaching staff, followed by secondary and middle-school students. Notwithstanding the possibility of adjustments, the indicative calendar will be: Phase 1 - Teaching and Non-Teacher Staff - September 6th to 17th Phase 2 – High School School Students – September 20th to October 1st Phase 3 – Middle students – October 4th to 15th."  Source: https://archive.vn/CmZpz

The General Directorate of Health published this Tuesday the norms for the next academic year.  Use of masks:  • Students aged 10 or over must wear a mask;  • For children attending primary school, the use of a mask is strongly recommended but not mandatory;  • The use of a mask must always be adapted to the clinical situation, based on a case-by-case assessment, by the treating physician.  Testing:  Students in 7th grade or above, teachers and other staff will be tested during the first weeks of the school year, "in order to break any transmission chains". Testing will take place in three phases: Phase 1 will target teaching and non-teaching staff; Phase 2 will target for high-school students; and Phase 3 will target students in the 3rd cycle of basic education.  Tests can also be carried out according to the evolution of the epidemiological situation. In addition to individual measures, Health Authorities may determine collective measures, advising that the closure of any establishment should only be considered in high-risk situations.  Source: https://archive.vn/Ntx2s

The use of a masks on the streets is now no longer mandatory in Portugal however the General Directorate of Health (DGS) recommends to continue to use a mask in certain situations.    (...) The DGS advises the use of a mask "when the occurrence of groups of people is expected or whenever it is not possible to maintain the recommended physical distance".    The DGS also recommends its use on the street by "most vulnerable people", namely "with chronic diseases or immunosuppression states with increased risk for severe Covid-19", whenever "moving outside their place of residence".    (...) The use of the mask will continue to be mandatory "in educational, teaching and nursery establishments", in "commercial spaces and service provision establishments", in "public buildings", in "cinemas or similar" in "collective passenger transport" and "in workplaces, whenever physical distance is not possible".    The wearing of the mask will continue to be mandatory also in "residential establishments for the elderly (ERPI), units of the National Network of Continuous Integrated Care (RNCCI) and other structures and residential responses for children, young people and people with disabilities, applicants and beneficiaries of international protection and reception of victims of domestic violence and human trafficking".    It is also mandatory to wear a mask by people "with SARS-CoV-2 infection or with symptoms" of the disease and by people considered to be in "contact of a confirmed case of covid-19", except when they are alone "in their place of isolation".    Source: https://archive.vn/8LyQz    Note: Downgraded to 2 since masks are only recommended, and not mandatory, in some situations (and for certain groups) when on the street.

Costa added that the complete vaccination rate against covid-19 is at 83.4% and that, next week, it will reach the expected 85%, so the country will go from a state of contingency to a state of alert."  Measures that will come into force on October 1st include;  - Restaurants with no maximum limit of people per group; - Mandatory mask in theaters and events; - The digital certificate is still required for major cultural, sporting or corporate events; - End of capacity limits, namely for weddings and baptisms and cultural shows and popular festivals. António Costa explained that spectators will be required to present a digital certificate in order to access "major cultural events", but it will be up to the DGS to define what these events are. On the use of masks in shows, António Costa explained that it will be mandatory "whenever there is no distance of two meters between people"."  Source: https://archive.vn/T0Qu1

"The prime minister, António Costa, announced this Thursday the lifting of several restrictions, with effect from 1 October.  Costa added that the complete vaccination rate against covid-19 is at 83.4% and that, next week, it will reach the expected 85%, so the country will go from a state of contingency to a state of alert."  One of the measures announced was the extension of the requirement to wear face masks in public transport.   Source: https://archive.vn/T0Qu1
Bans continue to apply, particularly for non-essential travel, for travellers from certain countries.  Source: https://archive.vn/OzX5n

October will bring a new phase of deconfinement plan which includes the reopening of bars and clubs, after more than a year and a half. This implies that these establishments will no longer be able to benefit from the simplified lay-off – an extraordinary regime that allows employers to reduce working hours or suspend employment contracts and in which the government provide support to pay employees salaries.   In August last year, this measure was only been available to employers were required to close (total or partial) facilities and establishments due to a governmental order. In March, the access to the simplified lay-off was made more flexible, also allowing companies fully or partially closed due to for example the interruption of global supply chains, or suspension or cancellation of orders, to benefit from this regime.  Bars and clubs that reopen but still face challenges, will be able to access, as an alternative, support for the progressive recovery. This scheme is aimed at employers with losses of at least 25% and provides support for the payment of salaries and allows employers to reduce the number of employees, however, this has limits that vary depending on the company's situation.  The Ministry of Labor also announced that the "lay-off" measure will not end and may be “used whenever there are situations of suspension of activities due to a governmental decision”.   Source: https://archive.vn/CPaXT

Portugal is in a countrywide State of Alert. Under the State of Alert, the Portuguese Government can impose obligatory quarantine for individuals infected with COVID-19 and individuals deemed by health officials to require special medical observation. The Government of Portugal announced a phased deconfinement plan for the gradual lifting of restrictions based on the overall vaccination rate in Portugal. The plan, implemented in three phases, is in Phase 3.    Phase 3: Beginning October 1    Restaurants, bars, disco, cafés continue to function under normal hours at full capacity (with no maximum number of people per group, both indoors and terraces)  Max capacity at commercial/retail spaces increased (venue dependent)  Cultural events/shows continue to function under normal hours at full capacity    Presentation  COVID EU Digital Certificate will no longer be necessary to access:  - group classes in gyms, spas and spas  - restaurants  - tourist establishments or local accommodation  - gambling establishments and casinos    Presentation of the EU COVID Digital Certificate remains necessary to access:  - bars and clubs    Masks - Indoors: Mandatory while using public transportation, elder care facilities, hospitals, theaters, large event spaces such as stadiums and arena, public spaces such as shopping centers, and supermarkets.     Sources: https://archive.vn/gKHok  https://archive.vn/no2tZ    Note: All work areas are now open. However, bars and nightclubs require the use of the covid certificate, so the coding remains unchanged to reflect closures for people without a covid certificate exemption.
Policy remains unchanged.    Source: https://archive.vn/no2tZ

Measures that will come into force on October 1st include;    - Restaurants with no maximum limit of people per group;  - Mandatory mask in theaters and events;  - The digital certificate is still required for major cultural, sports or corporate events;  - End of capacity limits, namely for weddings and baptisms and cultural shows and popular festivals. António Costa explained that spectators will be required to present a digital certificate in order to access "major cultural events" (...) On the use of masks in shows, António Costa explained that it will be mandatory "whenever there is no distance of two meters between people"."    According to the Director General of Health "To access to cultural events that are held with capacity for over 1,000 spectators indoors (rooms or similar) and over 5,000 spectators in an open environment (outdoor events), the presentation of the EU COVID Digital Certificate or proof of negative SARS-COV-2 negative test is required." "Before boarding, all passengers must present a certificate with a negative result of one of the following tests for screening of SARS-CoV-2 (...) Third country nationals without legal residency in Portugal will be refused entry if they do not hold a valid negative COVID-19 test or a recognised vaccination or recovery certificate.    (...) in addition to the COVID-19 test, passengers arriving from the following countries must undergo a 14 days mandatory quarantine in their homes, or in the places indicated by the health authorities and pre-register before travelling.?  India, Nepal, South Africa    (...) Passengers who have an EU-issued COVID-19 digital green certificate (EU DCC) or a non EU-issued certificate stating full vaccination or recovery from COVID-19.    The following passengers are allowed to transit through, enter and exit from Portugal:    European Union nationals, nationals of the of Schengen associated countries and their family members  Third-country nationals with legal residence in a European Union member state  Third-country nationals travelling for professional reasons, study, family reunification, health or humanitarian reasons  Nationals and legal residents of the following countries, provided that they are arriving on a direct flight or transiting only through the international area of any other airport:  Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Jordan, Kuwait, Macau, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Ukraine, United States of America, United Kingdom, Uruguay  Passengers holding valid EU Digital COVID Certificate or vaccination/recovery certificate issued by a non-EU country that accepts the EU Digital COVID Certificate are allowed to travel to Portugal for non-essential purposes.    Arriving to Portugal by Land  No restrictions of entrance.    Arriving to Portugal by Sea  Same rules as arriving by air apply.    Sources: https://www.emirates.com/pt/english/help/covid-19/travel-requirements-by-destination/ (unable to archive)  https://archive.vn/6ZQFt    Note: Even though there are no entrance restrictions by land the code remains unchanged since the majority of travelers from non-EU countries arrive by air or sea and significant restrictions remain in place for essential and/or non-essential travels from numerous countries.

Visitors must:    - present EU COVID Digital Certificate or proof of negative test  - carry out the visits at a previously scheduled time and with a limited time (not to exceed 90 minutes)  - respect the limit of visitor per resident or user at a time  - respect physical distance from users, respiratory etiquette and hand hygiene  - use a mask, preferably surgical, during the entire period of stay in the institution  - do not take personal items, food or other products  - do not walk around the institution or use the users' sanitary facilities  - ensure that the visit takes place in its own space, spacious and with airing conditions  - visitors who test positive for COVID-19 should inform the local health authority if they have visited the institution within 48 hours before the onset of symptoms  - prioritise communication with the user via video call or telephone  - if visitors have signs or symptoms suggestive of COVID-19 or have had contact with a suspected or confirmed case of COVID-19 in the last 14 days they should refrain from conducting the visit    Source: https://archive.vn/no2tZ    Note: Code remains unchanged since the aforementioned measures apply to all visitors (who must present a proof of negative test/vaccination certificate - i.e. there are no exceptions)
